name: Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Hollister Resource Area
description: The federal government has set aside roughly 15,000 acres of Fort Ord¿s undeveloped back country for management by the BLM to protect rare species and other natural habitats. Most of this land is located between the developed part of Fort Ord and Highway 68 and includes oak woodlands, dense chaparral shrublands, rolling grassy hills, wetlands, and ponds. The BLM habitat area will provide homes for 35 species of rare plants and animals, including small annual flowers, unique chaparral shrubs, black legless lizards, tiger salamanders, ornate shrews, blue butterflies, and tiny fairy shrimp. The BLM coordinates the development of a detailed management plan (CRMP) that will guide management of all the natural habitats at Fort Ord. CSUMB, UC Santa Cruz, Monterey County, California State Parks, and local cities as well as other public and nonprofit agencies and organizations will also be involved in the development and implementation of the management plan. Additionally, uniformed BLM staff, including law enforcement rangers, patrol the lands to enhance public enjoyment of the land and to assure that natural resources and public safety are protected.

Additionally, VRB houses an IPP preschool class, which serves students with severe speech impediments.

Virginia Rocca Barton Schoolâ€™s mission is to provide students with a quality education, provide a safe environment to learn and thrive in, and to motivate our students to break away from the cycles of subjugation. name: University of California Cooperative Extension UCCE
description: UCCE conducts research and provides education at the county level- in agriculture, the environment, community nutrition and youth development.   As regards agriculture, specifically plant pathology, UCCE  uses careful field assessments and thorough lab analyses to assist growers in reducing pesticide use and crop loss.As regards nutrition: The Family Nutrition Education Program provides free curriculum to schools, trains volunteers to provide nutrition education to community members, and participates in projects that improve health literacy and help youth develop good nutrition and fitness habits. Funded by the Food Stamp Program which also helps participants to purchase nutritious foods for better diet, Family Nutrition Education offers menus, recipes, nutrition classes, newsletters, fotonovelas, hand-outs, and access to a library of videos, books and display items with a nutrition theme. As regards youth development: UCCE's program develops programs for youth in science, technology, environmental stewardship and natural resource education in Santa Cruz and Monterey Counties and serves as an educational resource by developing and disseminating science, technology, environmental stewardship and natural resource education information relevant and useful to youth, associated organizations, and agencies.

name: Clinica de Salud Del Valle de Salinas (CSVS)
description: CSVC is a multi-site health care center, offering comprehensive primary care services and dental to farm worker families throughout Monterey County. Six health care centers are strategically located with access to rural and underserved communities.CSVS began as a street front clinic with volunteer health workers in 1980. In 1989, it became the only federally qualified health care center in Monterey County. There are now six health clinics: Castroville, Sanborn (Salinas), Greenfield, Circle (Salinas), Soledad, and King City.  In Monterey County¿s 3,324 square miles, fully 85% of  its population lives within fifteen minutes of a Clinica de Salud site.The total number of patient visits made yearly now reach 70,000!  20 state of the art clinicians, including physicians, pediatricians, physician assistants, nurse practitioners and dentists are available. They are especially proud of their comprehensive outreach programs which include:   Cal-ASET Comprehensive injury and prevention education for farmworkers and their employers in the tri-county area Provide Health Promoter¿s services to farmworkers Community Service Networking Coalition of 40 agencies (Score) led by the Clinica regularly present social services to the isolated areas of south county Interagency linkages and support throughout Monterey County Health Promoters¿ Service Outreach into homes, labor camps, fields, and schools Medical needs assessment/health and disease intervention            Health Education Transportation

name: Head Start Program (MCOE)
description: Head Start is a federally funded program that serves low income children and their families. Begun in 1965 to give low-income  three- and four-year-old children a ¿Head Start¿ on becoming successful individuals in a society, the program offers a comprehensive, multi-disciplinary approach to provide a wide range of services to enrolled children and their families. Services include health and nutrition screening, kindergarten readiness, social services referrals, and home management training. The program functions with an overall goal of bringing about a greater degree of ¿social competence¿ in children. Social competence is defined as a child¿s everyday effectiveness in dealing with both present environment and later responsibilities in school and life. Services are offered to met the special needs of children with disabilities.

It has an extensive collection of furnishings, costumes, books, manuscripts, and other artifacts.

The Monterey History and Art Association is the non-profit umbrella organization that operates the Museum of Monterey.

name: Parents' Place- Pacific Grove Adult Education
description: Parent Education Program, children-birth-age 3, come to weekly class with parents. This is a community center for educating parents that are expecting, new parents, etc.  They are working on supporting parents, teaching them, exploring different ways of being a successful parent. ¿A place for smiles, fun, growth, and continual change.¿   (see continued Description below)    Parents¿ Place is a division of Pacific Grove Adult School, which is funded by the City of Pacific Grove.  Parents¿ Place gives new parents (newborns to age 3) a place to come to learn the latest information on good parenting skills, to have a place to meet and share with other new parents, and to have a safe place to come to share problems and get good advice.  Parents¿ Place is a great place for kids to play with each other, do art and science projects, and sing songs while their parents are learning.  Parents¿ Place helps parents learn how to play with their kids.  Parents¿ Place has a great library of books, videos, and audiotapes on things like needs of a child, disciplining with love, dealing with sibling rivalry, nutrition for kids, and even the parents¿ well-being.
projects: We want someone to make a video that details the methods used in the school, so that people in other towns can start a Parents¿ Place in their town.   We would like people who would like to teach--this requires being a parent, but all training is provided.  We would like someone to computerize our library system.   An ambitious student might be interested in starting a Spanish-language outreach program.

RISE Recruitment in Science Education
description: The mission of the RISE Program (Recruitment in Science Education) is to support and encourage under privileged students from the Salinas and Marina areas to expand their interest in science and math.  The intention of the program is to increase the enrollment of under-represented populations in the Earth Systems Science and Policy (ESSP) Department at California State University at Monterey Bay.  The RISE Program  recruits students in the 6th grade and takes the jouney with them all the way through 12th grade. The program guides students to college through education, mentors, encouragement, friendship, scholorarships, and enthusiasm, creating a clearly defined path to college.
projects: Many opportunities are available, please come in and talk to us!!!

name: Watsonville Taller de Ciencia-Parks and Recreation Community Center
description: The Watsonville Taller de Ciencia is a local community science workshop in a California-wide program funded by National Science Foundation to bring hands-on science to kids in low-income communities.  Kids and adults (not too many adults come) are free to come and interact with the exhibits, play with the animals, work in the garden, play musical instruments, or, most importantly, build things.  They have three workbenches and a bunch of simple tools and all manner of supplies and materials.  They have several dozen science projects as models sitting around and the students can build whatever they want with help and supervision.  They also give classes to schools, three per week.  These happen on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday at 12:30.  Right now, they work with one alternative high school, and two elementary schools. It is an extraordinary atmosphere that you really have to experience to appreciate.

name: California Mini-Corps
description: The California Mini-Corps School-Year Program was initiated in 1974. The school year programs evolved from the Mini-Corps Summer Program. The idea for a corps of people from rural migrant background to work not only in the summer school, but also in the regular school year was born, and put into action in 1974. The Mini-Corps students would use their talent and dedication to work in migrant impacted classrooms, and would be the link between the migrant community and the schools. They would be personally acquainted with each child and their family- they could share their hopes and frustrations. Most important, they would be role models that hopefully would raise the aspiration of migrant children. Through the summer and school year programs the Mini-Corps students provide services to the migrant children of California.   Objectives: Provide direct categorical services to Migrant Children, which match or exceed performance standards prescribed in the California Master Plan.  Increase the numbers of professionals who are sensitive and committed to the needs of migrant children.

description:
CLEOS/FCC(Family Child Care)
provides a small home setting for child care for children 6wks.-12 yrs. With a ratio of 1:6 FCC offers opportunities for children to get individualized attention and to develop a positive sense of self.All providers must offer age appropriate activities for the children in their care.
MONTEREY ROAD CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTER
Serves children and families affiliated with the Armed Forces, MIIS, and CSUMB. Our purpose is to reduce the conflict between parental duties and responsiblilities of work for parent of the children in our care. We do this by providing quality, affordable care that meets nationally recognized standards for excellence.  We involve families in the process of planning educational experiences for their children.  Our staff are among the best trained in the country, and many of them have more than a decade of experience working the young children.Professionally trained kitchen staff serve two hot meals and two snacks per day in accordance with USDA guidelines. We have numerous special events that families participate in both during business hours and occasionally on nights or weekends. We serve approximately two hundred families on a daily basis.
PORTER YOUTH CENTER
Our Center's purpose is to offer quality, affordable care that meets national standards for excellence. We offer services to families affiliated with the Armed Forces,CSUMB and MIIS and provide quality educational activities for children in Kindergarten through age 18.  Boys and Girls Club of America and 4-H are part of our baseline programming.  We provide services to 100 plus children per day at our center.
projects:

description: The Probation Department's Youth Center is a low-security, coeducational, residential treatment facility located in East Salinas. It is one of only a few secured juvenile treatment centers in the state. The Youth Center is comprised of three dormitories with a total capacity of 85 residents. Probation staff, Behavioral Health therapists and teachers from the County Office of Education work cooperatively and collaboratively with outside providers in a team approach that works with residents and their parents and/or guardians to understand and address the causation of the residents' delinquent behavior, gang involvement, or drug and alcohol addictions. The Youth Center's therapeutic environment is designed to work to help residents develop insight into their personal situations, to instill impulse control by improving personal coping mechanisms, and to encourage pro-social attitudes and behaviors.

name: Pueblo Del Mar Recovery Community, a project of Sun Street Centers
description: Pueblo del Mar provides services under the management of our parent center, Sun Street Centers. The mission of SSC is to prevent the occurrence or recurrence of problems related to alcohol/drug use in Monterey County. This is accomplished through programs and activities which overcome denial of the fact and nature of problems related to alcohol and drug use, promote public and private policies to discourage inappropriate alcohol and drug use, and result in communitities which support abstinence based recovery of alcoholics, addicts and their families. We welcome participants who are but not limited to, indigent, very-low, low and moderate-income individuals and their families. Pueblo del Mar opened its doors in December of 1998. The Nancy Dodd Community Center was recently opened this past July of 2003. Pueblo del Mar is a transitional living program for families who have committed to their recovery process and are moving towards self-sufficiency. We serve homeless families who have completed a residential recovery program, or who can document that they have partici8pated in a 12-step Sobriety Program for at least 3 months.

description: The official vision statement of Casa de Protección addresses these issues by saying, ¿As we meet the children¿s physical needs, we can introduce them to what is most important of all- the love of Jesus Christ. Through the love of Jesus we are able to break out of the destructive cycles that they were born into, and look forward to the children becoming productive men and women in the days to come.¿

name: Marina Larger Library
description: The Purpose of our organization is to build a larger library in Marina.  In addition to building the library we also intend to contribute significantly to the programs and resources available to the public.  Our group is in coordination with the Marina Library - part of the Monterey County Free Library System and The Friends of the Marina Library,
projects: Our project as a Capstone offers a wealth of opportunities for the student to not only meet cutting edge website technology issues but also to understand, related to and answer the needs of the users in a library.  The areas of interest in the library and the library website use are as vast as the individuals that use them.  The exciting aspect of this project is realizing the full potential of the bridge that the website creates between the patrons and the library.  The bridge is not just two way, but runs in multiple directions because of literary, municipal and societal demands.  Our library especially meets the needs of a very diverse group of people.  If we are able to communicate our programs, needs and accomplishments via the website we increase the likelihood that patrons will find the answers to their individual needs.

name: Poder Popular an initiatve of the Center for Community Advocacy, CCA
description: Poder popular is an organization that works to improve the health and well being of farmworkers, their families and the communities where they live through grassroots organizing and leadership development.  in each of the three communities where poder popular operates, east salinas, gonzales and greenfield, residents and their allies representing business (including agribusiness), non-profits, religious institutions, government and education, have worked together to develop and action plans which provide a framework for making community improvements.  these plans include improved education, recreational and employment opportunities for youth, improved relations between residents and city officials, reductions in criminal activity and improved cityinfrastructure.  early successes in the implementation of these plans include improvements to local parks, increased lighting and increased cultural and artistic opportunities.
projects: Research with environmental justice issues of farm workers/health/safety. Developing training materials. Computer tutoring. Helping groups make presentations using media. Business development. CAPSTONES PREFERRED.

These organizing tools help COPA to identify and organize to ensure the needs of families & communities are met. COPA is a broad based (multi-issue) organization made up of 24 institutions (schools, churches/ synagogues/ mosques, and other non-profits) working together to engage ordinary citizens in public life to build power to address pressures facing our families in the Central Coast region.

name: Access Monterey Peninsula
description: Access Monterey Peninsula (AMP) is a community nonprofit that was formed to help manage community access to local cable TV systems. Our vision is to serve the seven cities and three school districts of the Peninsula and unincorporated areas of the County with a full array of exciting access services, equipment, and facilities. AMP is led by an eleven-member Board of Directors representing the community at large, education, and local government. Executive Director, Paul Congo, came to AMP in May 1999, and is supported by Programming Director Kit Clements and Community Services Director Jim Martin. These staff members are all media and television professionals with experience in developing PEG services over many years. The mission of Access Monterey Peninsula is to provide 1) facilities (including access to equipment) to create video programming and other media; 2) training in video production and other media; 3) playback of programming currently on three channels and eventually up to six channels on the Monterey Peninsula; 4) production assistance; 5) technical support; and 6) volunteer management. Our facilities, equipment, and services are available to the community at-large, schools and youth, and local government agencies.

Community Agroecology Network
description:
The Community Agroecology Network(CAN)works together with rural comunities in Latin America to support sustainable livelihoods and environments by intergrating action education participatory action research, and trade innovations.

CAN is a U.S.-based non-profit organization that was founded in 2001 in response to the global coffee crisis, which plunged an estimated 20 million families into dire poverty. The founders initiated CAN after visiting several Latin American farming communities facing similar challenges.

Our objective is to link the grassroots struggles and efforts of these communities in a network of rural farmers and consumers that work together to support self-sufficiency and sustainable farming practices. CAN's vision is to work with rural communities to develop the capacity to become economically and environmentally sustainable through agriculture and social empowerment.

Our mission is committed to: Action research - farm-based research that engages investigators and farmers in collaborative efforts to improve local sustainable farming practices Education; community education, technical assistance, leadership development, consumer education, internships, and ongoing exchanges and communication between the member communities Marketing;  adding value to the rural processes of production and developing producer controlled markets that support local communities and create direct links with consumers.

CAN has developed a \fair trade direct\" coffee marketing system
population_size: which directly links coffee co-ops in Central America with U.S. consumers. By cutting out the middlemen and acting as a nonprofit intermediary
projects: CAN helps farmers receive a just and sustainable price for their coffee. CAN connects growers and consumers in a \"global village farmers market\"
web: which brings together economic viability and ecological farming practices
issues:
including transitioning to organic production and reforestation.

Hospice of the Central Coast Griefbusters
description:
To help children and teens move through the natural grief process in a healthy way so that they emerge with coping skills that may be used throughout life.

Understanding the loss of someone close and getting beyond the trauma and grief is very difficult for anyone - especially young people. Griefbusters can help.

Hospice of the Central Coast's nationally award-winning program gently guides young people and their families through the grieving process. We work with young people individually and in groups and are also available to meet with families and school staff.  Upon request, we conduct presentations about grief and loss.

Our Griefbusters staff members are highly trained, skilled volunteers, not licensed therapists. We'll listen patiently, offer compassionate support, and answer your questions - in a confidential setting, free of charge.
projects: A student is welcome to use any aspect of Griefbusters to create a campstone project.  We are willing to support research and creativity.

name: Coastlands, The, Aptos Foursquare Church
description:
We are delighted to help in the process of each person getting to know God better. Thus, as a church our focus is:

1. TO LOVE and accept you just as you are, for what you are, no matter where you are. Our love for you is unconditional, and we want to surround you with a sense of acceptance and belonging that we have found in Jesus. 

2.TO MEND and recover you from any points of hurt, distortion, fear, torment or imbalance in the way you think, feel or chose to live. Jesus loves us where we are, but takes us to where we were designed to live. 

3.TO TRAIN and instruct you in the many ways that God thinks, feels and moves -- as revealed in the Bible -- so that you are better able to understand and obey the way of life Jesus has taught. It is called the Kingdom of God. 

4.TO SEND and release you into the particular course of life and ministry service that God has chosen for you. Jesus has uniquely gifted you for your assignment, and the whole Body benefits most when each part is encouraged to be themselves.

name: Community of Caring, Monterey Peninsula
description: Nonprofit organization dedicated to improving the quality of life for youth and families in our communities. This collaboration pursues initiatives targeted toward achieving progress on priority issues identified by the TELLUS project and community discussion. The Goals of Community of Caring Monterey Peninsula are: Promote a healthy set of community norms and values Foster a better connection between the community and the education system Embrace and promote our rich diversity Reduce substance abuse Enhance personal safety Expand parent support and education mechanisms Create additional activities for our youth Reduce the incidence of HIV infection and teen pregnancy We are pursuing our mission by encouraging schools, businesses, local governments, service providers, religious organizations, and families to embrace and include the Community of Caring values and program elements in their own activities. We are also working to serve as a networking tool for all of those that serve youth and their families on the Monterey Peninsula. By networking, we hope to address gaps and overlaps in programs and services, and pursue collaborative opportunities.
projects: Website and connected databases, video- film opportunities to document youth service.

description: Global Majority promotes non-violent conflict resolution education, meditation and advocacy. We believe that principled dialogue is imperative and must replace violent conflict if mankind is to thrive.

name: Vista Verde Middle School - Greenfield USD
projects: POSTPONE Program Math Academy: to help kids with advanced math.  School garden.

name: H.A. Hyde Elementary School-PVUSD
description: To provide education to children living within the attendance area.

name: H.A. Hyde Elementary School - PVUSD
description: H.A. Hyde Elementary School is part of Pajaro Valley Unified School District. School improvement is a high priority at the Pajaro Valley Unified School District (PVUSD).  We have fully implemented class size reduction in grades K-3 with a 20:1 student/teacher ratio.     Our nationally recognized New Teacher Project provides ongoing coaching and support to improve instruction.

name: Haven Counseling Center
description: The mission of the Kern Child Abuse Prevention Council / Haven Counseling Center is to be a nonprofit organization dedicated to the prevention of child abuse and neglect through advocacy and education.
projects: Students interested in 'system and strength-based' approach are welcome to discuss Capstone opportunities.
issues: Health & Human Services|Housing & Homelessness|Violence Prevention|Women's Issues|Youth Development

name: Santa Cruz County Human Resources Agency
description: HRA provides social services, employment and training services, veteran's services, income maintenance and public guardian to families, adults, and children.  Programs include:  child welfare services, adoptions, foster care, self-sufficiency, job training partnership act (JTPA), aid to families with dependent children(AFDC), food stamps, medi-cal, GAIN, cal-learn, the public guardian, veterans services, adult protective services, in-home supportive services, child care, summer youth employment, day care licensing.
projects: Unknown-varies

name: Linscott Charter School
description: K-8. Linscott Charter School is a parent participation school located in Watsonville, California. We were formed to create an environment emphasizing individualized, active, hands-on learning for children in Kindergarten through Eighth Grade. Located in a historic building near downtown Watsonville, we focus on community, in and out of the classroom.

name: Gabilan Elementary School
description: Provide a vigorous, high-quality, engaging and targeted educational program that prepares our diverse students to meet or exceed district and state standards, and state and national performance targets that teaches the skills to inspire students to be life-long learners, and supports success in higher education, employment, citizenship, and family life.
projects: Academic support: technology related; fitness-related

name: Watershed Institute, The
description: The Watershed Institute is a direct action, community-based coalition of researchers, restoration ecologists, eductiors, students, planners, and area volunteers dedicated to restoring the waterseds of the Monterey Bay region.
projects: Many for BUS, Integrated Studies, ESSP.

name: Kathryn Hughes Elementary School
description: Our mission is to promote all students with the love of learning, to provide a safe and integrated academic and social environment, and a comprehensive curriculum.

name: Interfaith Outreach of Carmel
description: Interfaith Outreach of Carmel is an interfaith organization dedicated to extending a helping hand to the Monterey County Community.

name: Interfaith Outreach of Carmel
Members of IOC faith communities have responded to community needs more effectively as a group
status: making Joining Hands to Make a Difference an integral part of who we are. Early examples included: supporting the Food Bank for Monterey County
address_street: All Saints’ and Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Food Pantries and the Rice Plus Project that provides 2
address_city: 000 pounds of rice and beans in family-sized packages monthly
address_state: loading Nancy Costello’s truck as she distributes food to migrant agricultural workers
address_zip: donating blankets to Shelter Outreach Plus
description: and facilitating donations of women’s clothing to the Women Alive! shelter in Salinas run by Dorothy's Place. This last activity has now become a recurring activity of the Friends
population_size: other IOC members and the Yellow Brick Road
projects: providing pajamas
web: underwear and warm clothing for homeless women.

name: For 2008
status: the IOC planned a showcase of health and human services nonprofit agencies to inform the public
address_street2: as well as other groups involved in social justice issues
address_city: about the wealth of free or low-cost services available in our county. As the IOC planned this fair
description: which was planning a similar event on the same day. As a result
projects: eventually called the We Care Fair
web: at Del Monte Center in Monterey. The Community of Caring was working with Pacific Grove and Marina High Schools
issues: with their focus being on finding volunteer opportunities for youth. The focus of the combined fair was on volunteering
org_types: with health and human services organizations also represented. The goal of the fair was to foster a community in which service is valued

name: In 2008
status: the IOC co-sponsored a Hunger Symposium hosted by St. Philip’s Lutheran Church. The featured speakers were former Congressman Leon Panetta and David Gist from Bread for the World.

name: As a part of the IOC monthly general meetings
status: speakers are sometimes invited to brief members on their activities and needs. Speakers in the past have included a representative of the Agriculture and Land-Based Training Association (ALBA). This organization works with farm workers to train them to be organic farmers and start their own businesses. Farmers bring their produce to churches or schools for sale. Another speaker from Shelters in a Storm spoke about preparing for emergencies and how local neighborhoods and faith communities can assist in this regard.

name: In 2009
status: the IOC arranged venues in participating faith communities for the Compassionate Care Alliance in partnership with Hospice Advance Health Care Planning Workshops.  We have also provided venues for community forums conducted to pursue the idea of a new Monterey Bay Village program
address_street: designed to keep seniors living in their homes longer.

name: Members of the IOC celebrate together during such occasions as the 2009 Community Thanksgiving Eve Interfaith service held at the Unitarian Universalist Church of the Monterey Peninsula.
In the planning stages for 2010 is a faith explorations series designed to increase our understanding of the tenets of each other’s faith.
Also being planned in 2010 is a benefit shop that will enable us to provide more than helping hands
status: which are not always sufficient to deal with life-sustaining issues that stem from financial realities. An IOC benefit shop could directly address the IOC mission by tapping into the initial premise of the IOC: that we can do things collectively that we are unable to do individually.

name: Front Street, Inc./Drake House
description: Drake House is a 49 bed residential facility in Monterey serving seniors with severe and persistent mental health issues; primarily schizophrenia. Front Street Inc. has facilities in 4 counties; Monterey, Santa Cruz, San Mateo and Santa Clara. Drake House is the only facility in Monterey County .

name: Santa Cruz Indymedia c/o Resource Center for Non Violence
description: Indymedia emerged from the clouds of tear gas that filled the streets of Seattle in 1999 as a tool for the creation of radical, accurate, and passionate tellings of truth. Then and now, the stories told through Indymedia come from the hearts and minds of people on the frontlines of the struggle for justice against tyranny. Since 1999, Indymedia has grown into a network of more than 160 Independent Media Centers (IMCs) all over the world by means of a commitment to equality, decentralization and autonomy.

name: Junior Achievement of Silicon Valley & Monterey Bay
description:
JA volunteers teach kids about the world of business, how the free enterprise system works and the value of staying in school.

JA is a K-12 program, the program is always free to the schools and the prepackaged curriculum meets State of California collelation standards.

name: Housing Authority of Monterey County/Pueblo Del Mar
description: The Housing Authority serves low-income families in Monterey County by providing rental assistance for low-income rental housing related services to support family self-sufficiency.

name: Housing Authority of Monterey County/Housing Voucher Program
description: Special programs in the Housing Authority include landlord outreach and marketing for rental properties.

name: Monterey-Salins Transit Mobility/Travel Assistance Program
description: The Mobility Management Center of MST is starting up a new Travel Assistance Program to support seniors and those with disabilities to use public transportation safely and with confidence. The program will assess needs of consumers and provide training and one on one assistance for ADA.

name: Life Is For Everyone, Inc.
description: L.I.F.E. `s mission is to provide increased educational, life and ethics skills for at-risk elementary and middle school youth in a safe after-school environment in East Salinas. A structured study and learning program based on individual student needs is setup for each student. East Salinas elementary and middle school students attend the study / work sessions on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoon sessions.
projects: A Capstone project could be the review and assessment of the Life Is For Everyone process and program with a view toward providing the documentation and recommendations to replicate this successful after-school program at other locations in Salinas or other locations in Monterey County. Capstore Project personnel would work with the progam Director and  President of the L.I.F.E. Board of Directors to accomplish this goal.

name: Nipomo High School
description: Summer school for entire school district.
projects: Out of CSUMB service area

name: Lyceum of Monterey County
description: To inspire a life-long love of learning through enrichment programs that stimulate intellectual promise, individual creativity and academic achievement. Children ages K-12. After-school programs, summer programs and academic events (e.g. History Day, Spelling Bee, Mock Trail).
projects: We would love to work with a student in Human Services, Marketing, Communication, Finance, Management, etc. on their capstone project. We have many special events that will assist a student in their learning non-profit management - call us today!

name: Rose Ferrero Elementary School
description: Elementary School.

La Gloria Elementary School
description: Gonzales Unified School District is committed to providing a quality education that prepares all students to be lifelong learners and contributing members of society through comprehensive programs provided by skilled and motivated staff.
projects: After school tutorial: establish a program and see it through for 1 year, then evaluate the success.

name: Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, MERITO Program
description: Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary's (MBNMS) Multicultural Education for Resource Issues Threatening Oceans (MERITO) mission is to increase protection of sanctuary resources by building a greater understanding of ocean-related threats within our diverse communities by providing opportunities to engage in marine protection.  MERITO implements ocean and watershed conservation after-school programs, adult education programs and family experiences in the Monterey County to reach its objectives.
projects: Database management.

name: Warner Davis Community School - MCOE Alternative Education Program
description: Community schools serve mandatory and other expelled students, students referred by a School Attendance Review Board, and other high-risk youths. The 360-minute minimum instructional day includes academic programs that provide challenging curriculum and individual attention to student learning modalities and abilities. Community school programs also focus on the development of pro-social skills and student self-esteem and resiliency. Community schools are intended to have low student-teacher ratios. Students benefit from learning support services that include school counselors and psychologists, academic and vocational counselors, and pupil discipline personnel. Students also receive collaborative services from county offices of education, law enforcement, probation, and human services agency personnel who work with at-risk youth. Community schools are supported by supplemental apportionment for community school attendance, in addition to base revenue funding.

name: Monterey County Parks-(North Monterey County Parks)
description: Provide quality recreation with a personal touch.
projects: Enviro studies interns- maybe a series of events, develop hikes/curriculum to present to the public.

name: Monterey Peninsula Regional Park District
description: To acquire, protect, and steward open space for public benefit and enjoyment. To protect the natural character and community value of those lands in perpetuity with best management practices.
projects: There are many opportunities related to the positions and placement areas already listed. All projects would be related to public open space management, conservation, education, and research.

name: Marina Children's Center
description: To provide a safe and nurturing environment for young children as well as an educational program. The program includes individual small group and large group activities, indoors and outdoors, focusing on physical activities, social skill development and muscular coordination.
projects: None.

name: Multiple Scleroisis Comm. Services
description: Our mission is to provide assistance for those with MS in our tri-county area. To inform the public about MS and sponsor programs that provide direct aid to people living with the daily challenges MS presents. MSCS is available as the first point of contact for newly diagnosed MS persons and their families who seek reliable information about the causes and effects of living with MS based on medical, scientific and real life experiences of others with MS.
issues: Technology|Social Services|Nutrition/Fitness|Law & Legal Services|Housing & Homelessness|Health & Human Services|Education|Advocacy

name: Monterey Co. Health Dept. STD Prevention Programs
description: Purpose of Public Health Bureau is to enhance,promote and protect the health of individuals,families and communities in Monterey County.

description: To Provide an environment where curiosity and creativity flourish, while both children and adults learn together through experience.

name: Neighborhood Networks Computer Center
description: To provide hands ion computer training and access for Del Monte Manor residents while sharing resources with our local community. Neighborhood Networks center endeavors and strive to prepare our community for increased educational, employment, and functional development in the 21st century age of technology.
projects: Developing strategic plan fund raising plan. Project and course development & adult education.

name: New Hope Baptist Church Youth Programs
New Hope Baptist Church Youth Programs
description: We believe by the Spirit of God to receive the Lord Jesus Christ as our savior. We engage, therefore, walk together in Christian love with the Holy Spirit. If there be difference of opinions, we will cheerfully recognize the right of the majority to govern. We also engage to maintain family and secret devotion, to study diligently the word of God. We further engage to watch over, to pray for each other unto every good word and work. We live to serve the Lord our God using the Holy Spirit.
projects: Open to idea.
issues: Youth Development|Women's Issues|Nutrition/Fitness|Music/Performance Arts|Housing & Homelessness|Health & Human Services|Foster Care|Education|Before/After School

name: Housing Resource Center (formerly Housing Advocacy Council)
description: The mission of the Housing Advocacy Council, a non-for-profit organization, is to assist and educate Monterey County residents in obtaining and maintaining affordable housing.  We accomplish this mission through our three main programs: 1) Emergency Rental Assistance Program- we give qualifying families who have experienced an emergency one month's rent so they do not have to incur the costs of moving, 2) Security Deposit Guarantee Program- we cosign with and give vouchers to tenants who are not able to pay the entire security deposit upfront but will pay it in installments over the course of their lease, and 3) Community Education Program- we offer workshops in the community on tenant rights and responsibilities, how to find a rental unit, and budgeting your money.
projects: None at this time.  I am interested in working with any students who would like to formulate a Capstone Project with our organization!

name: Santa Cruz County Office of Education, One Stop Career Center
description: serves high poverty, high risk youth in Watsonville. Services provided by SCOOE, Workforce Investment Act and the City of Watsonville for job skills, academic tutoring and mentoring

description: Teaching ESL to adults.

name: Juan Cabrillo Family Resource Center
Old Monterey Business Association
description: Promote and enhance ecomonic vitality and community spirit of Old Monterey. District covers 26 squares blocks of claifornia's most historic area. 475 businesses located in the district.

name: Workforce Investment Board - Monterey County
description: To provide strategic planning, policy development, and Oversight Evaluation of the local workforce investment system.  Provide leadership to support the best practices of the public and private sectors to create a dynamic, efficient and effective Workforce Investment Board.  Develop innovative models that effectively acquire and leverage alternative funding sources to offer access to all services. Contribute to a healthy economy that is filled with jobs that are built with integrity and offer positive experiences by empowering the community members and businesses with the knowledge and skills to be successful.
projects: Annual report writing assistance.

name: Pajaro Valley Historical Association (Bockius-Orr House, Volck Museum, Snyder Archive)
description: Promote history of the Pajaro Valley which includes parts of Santa Cruz, San Benito, and Monterey counties. To gather, preserve and exhibit historical items, to interpret for the general public and visitors and to maintain our historic facilities and grounds.
projects: House: working with our extensive clothing and accessories collection, as well as furnishings.

Partners for the Advancement of Teaching
description: PARTNERS provides professional development and curriculum resources for tri-county Monterey Bay area teachers and after school educators through community partnerships and program of research, workshops, and continuing education units and outreach to local area schools & educational institutionist.
projects: Expand and evaluate business plans.

name: Paso Robles High School
description: AVID, Advancement Via Individual Determination, is a pre-collegiate program designed to increase student performance and college eligibility among traditionally under-served student populations. AVID teaches students strategies for academic success, such as Cornell note-taking, Socratic Seminar, and WICR (Writing, Inquiry, Collaboration, and Reading) strategies and helps students realize their full potential.
projects: Students interested in working on special/capstone projects are encouraged to contact Anne Spohnhauer at aspohnhauer@king.prps.k12.ca.us with a project or service in mind to help better the AVID program at Paso Robles High School.

name: POSTPONE Peer Educator Program - CSUMB's PGCC
description:
The Monterey County Health Department's POSTPONE project is funded by the State of California's Community Challenge Grant. The Personal Growth and Counseling Center has entered into a collaborative relationship with the POSTPONE program to develop a Peer Mentor Program, whereby students at CSUMB are trained as educators in the areas of sexuality, risk reduction, and reproductive health issues.

These Peer Mentors then provide educational workshops to local high school students and fellow CSUMB students. The POSTPONE Teen Pregnancy Collaborative unites the efforts of our diverse populations to achieve healthy and responsible sexual attitudes through education and values, resulting in having an informed and respectable community. This promotes positive behavior changes at the individual, family and community levels, leading to prevention of teen pregnancy.
 
Our program targets two critical areas: pregnancy and sexually transmitted disease prevention and healthy decision making.

name: Pajaro Valley High School
description: Pajaro Valley High School is a community of unique individuals, acting as global citizens committed to life-long learning, stewarding the environment, and fostering artistic expression. Our goal is to create engaging, meaningful and academically rigorous curriculum that will prepare our students for broad possibilities upon graduation. to accomplish this we are organized into small learning communities incorporate collaboration among teachers, project-based learning, integrated projects, longer class periods, and ad advisory program.
projects: Will develop through relationship.

name: The Reading Center
description:
The Reading Center

Services for K-12 Students

A highly trained Reading Specialist provides individualized reading diagnosis and literacy instruction for K-12 students who struggle to read.

Once properly assessed

name: receive one-to-one tutoring or small groups tutoring. The tutors are
undergraduate and graduate CSUMB students who work under the direction
of the Center’s Reading Specialist and Reading Center faculty. The
tutors provide instruction tailored to meet the needs of students with
mild to severe reading and literacy challenges.
Individualized instruction using
research based reading methods along with ongoing assessment and
progress monitoring allow Reading Center staff

pinpoint areas of growth and challenge.

name: RUAP - Reciprocal University for the Arts Project
description: The Reciprocal University for the Arts Project (RUAP)is a shared project of California State University Monterey Bay's Visual and Public Arts Institute (VPA) and the Music and Performing Arts Institute (MPAI).   RUAP supports the development of relationships between the University and four local communities: Watsonville, Salinas, Seaside, and Monterey.   These relationships are embedded within our interdisciplinary and service-based arts curriculum.
projects: Community Based Projects are those endeavors that are not based within the structure of university curriculum. These projects typically evolve directly from the community and RUAP assists in facilitating the development of the project using strategies such as community artists, visiting artists in residence, students, faculty, and other community based organizations. Classes may become involved in an aspect of a project but do not define the structures and outcomes in the same way as a class based project.

name: 1st United Methodist Church
description: To develop trust in relationships that allow the discovery & elimination of societal & institutional roadblocks encountered by the homeless population their full return to full participation in community.

name: San Carlos School PTO
description:
San Carlos School, an educational ministry of San Carlos Cathedral Parish, is a Catholic, coeducational, TK-8 school. The school serves serveral local parishes and the surrounding communities. San Carlos School embraces families of all faiths who seek a safe and nurturing learning environment for their children.

Established in 1898 by the Sisters of St. Joseph of Carondolet, the school strives to develop in students a sense of responsibility both for themselves and the greater community. San Carlos School is committed to preparing students for academic excellence in high school and to be self-confident, lifelong learners who embody Gospel values. In this spirit, San Carlos School:

  • models and teaches Catholic Christian life;
  • integrates academic excellence with spiritual and moral development; and
  • creates a mutually supportive Catholic Christian community.
projects: Project could map into Capstone

name: San Juan School
description:
At San Juan School, student learning is our primary goal. We expect all students to
take responsibility for their own actions and to attend school every day so they can
benefit from the educational opportunities offered here. We expect all students in our
district to excel.
projects: Student Teaching

name: Elkhorn Elementary School
description: Elkhorn is in North Monterey County, a K-6 school aprox 650 students. Large portion of it's students are from migrant families. Most do not have access to modern technology in the home.Our goal is to give them as much hands on experiance as possable, at an early age so they are not so far behind their peers when they reach high school.
projects: To get students envoled with a student news letter, To update the schools web site /  make it more interactive. name: Friends Outside
description: Goal of Friends Outside is to help reduce the trauma of incarseration for prisoners and their families, to provide information that can lead to positive changes, and to assist post-release clients with their re-entry into the community.

name: Second/2nd Chance Family and Youth Services
description:
2ND Chance does exactly what its name implies; offers youth a second chance at life without judging, accusing, or pointing fingers. The organization is a voice for those who have none, the harbor that young people often need to find positive outlets in life other than gangs and drugs.

We provide them with the opportunity to empower themselves, set goals and take a deep look within to determine what to change. The relationship established between 2nd Chance and young people helps break the hard exterior and find a diamond in the rough.
projects: Same as above

name: Second Chance Family and Youth Services
description:
Established in 1989 by a group of community members who lived in East Salinas, the Second Chance Youth Program of Monterey County was formed to address the cries for help from youth involved in violence and gang activity.

Second Chance does exactly what its name imples:  offers youth a second chance at life without judging, accusing, or pointing fingers.  The organization is a voice fo those who have non, the harbor that young people often need to find positive outlets in life other than gangs and drugs.

name: Service Learning Institute
description: The mission of the Service Learning Institute is to foster and promote social justice by cultivating reciprocal service and learning partnerships among CSUMB students, faculty, staff and the surrounding tri-county community. The Service Learning Institute serves as the home of the California State University, Monterey Bay (CSUMB) service learning program. Housed in the division of Academic Affairs, as one of the University-Wide Academic Support Programs, the SLI serves as an instructional unit, an academic resource center, a center for developing community partnerships, and the home of an innovative student leadership program. The SLI has been recognized nationally for its work in helping students examine issues of justice, diversity and social responsibility through service learning.

name: Shelter Outreach Plus/ Counseling Art Therapy
description: The Salinas site of Shelter Outreach Plus provides emergency temporary shelter for up to 60 days for women and children at risk of homelesness due to domestic violence and other contributing factors. The site has a capacity of 12 families and is often full.

name: SLEWTHS project at Moss Landing Marine Labs
description: LEWTHS is an innovative project of sea lions and people working together to further marine education, research, and conservation. Together with its parent company Animal Training and Research, International, the projectï¿½s range of interests and goals encompasses all major areas of the marine mammal industry. SLEWTHS, as the non-profit arm of ATR Intl., has three main program directions: Research, Classes & Internships, and K-12 Programs.
projects: Program regularly works with ESSP students.

description: The Surfrider Foundation is a non-profit environmental organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of the world's oceans, waves and beaches for all people, through conservation, activism, research and education.

name: City of Marina Teen Center
description:
Our Teen Center in Marina mission is to keep the teens off the streets and out of trouble. Weekly we are involved in sport programs, music lessons, art programs, enviromental activities and our newest creation a computer and homework room with 06 and a video production and editing workshop to produce a documentary and commercial of the lives of teens in Marina computers. We do some drug,alcohol and pregnancy counciling for those that need it. And if we aren't able to help we find someone who can.

This proram operates out of a new (2009) Teen Center building with excellent computer lab, music room, skate park, recreation room and kitchen facilities.  The Teen Center serves breakfast daily to children on their way to school.
projects: We are in an ongoing video production workshop.We are making a documentary film and commercial on the lives of teenagers in Marina. The teens will be following each other around with cameras recording their activities. They will also be producing and editing and doing a viewing for the video.

issues: Advocacy|Education|Health & Human Services|Housing & Homelessness|Immigration |Law & Legal Services|Media|Social Services|Violence Prevention|Women's Issues|Youth Development

name: Del Monte Manor - Neighborhood Networks Computer Center
description: Mission Statement: The Mission of Neighborhood Networks COMPUTER CENTER - Del Monte Manor is to provide hands-on computer access, for our residents while sharing resources with our local Seaside community and connecting us all into the World Wide Global network. The Computer Center strives to be a comfortable place for learning and understanding basic computer systems and acquiring computer skills. We endeavor to continually create and recreate a fun, learning, nurturing environment to launch our users out onto the World Wide Global Network.

name: John XXIII AIDS Ministry
description: To provide housing and related services to people living with HIV/AIDS;and to generate and foster compassionate understanding, provide education and prevention activities, and emotional and end-of-life services to individuals and families at risk for, or living with, HIV/AIDS in Monterey and San Benito Counties.
projects: -Web site maintenance. -Look at agency's hardware and suggest improvements. -Data base builder. -Agency software Trainer. -Logistical support of agency Friendly Visitor Program.

AIDS Community Research Consortium
description:
Our mission is to support health and quality of life 
through compassionate and culturally appropriate programs that are responsive to the changing needs of those infected and affected by HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C. ACRC is dedicated to empowering its clients, communities, and its partner agencies through community-driven programming , education and consultation.
projects: Gardening project.

name: Army Community Services/AFTB-Outreach
description: Army Community Service (ACS) is the primary resource agency for developing, coordinating and delivering service member and family social services that contribute to overall morale and welfare. The staff at ACS believes that seeking support, information and education is a sign of family strength rather than an indication of difficulty.

name: Ag Against Hunger
description: Ag Against Hunger is a cleaning house for surplus crops from the Salinas and Pajaro Valleys. Our Mission is to alleviate hunger by providing a link between the agricultural community and food assistance organizations.
projects: Brochure creation, marketing/public relations opportunities.

name: Agriculture and Land Based Training Association-ALBA
description: The Agriculture and Land-Based Training Association (ALBA) provides educational and business opportunities for farm workers and aspiring farmers to grow and sell crops from two local farms in Monterey County, California. Our Mission is to advance economic viability, social equity and ecological land management among limited-resource and aspiring farmers. We work to create opportunities for family farms while providing education and demonstration on conservation, habitat restoration, and whole farm planning.

name: Alianza Charter Elementary School
description: K-6 Elementary School with: Two way language immersion program, Model 90/10 with eng. and Spanish speakers learning together.    Alianza's dual immersion program is a wonderful place to introduce ed students to learning and teaching in a span/eng bilingual classroom.
projects: We are open to a variety of student projects : literacy, science, math, multiculturalism, arts, sports, carreer education, partnerships with university.

name: Alliance on Aging - Administrative Offices
description:
The Alliance on Aging is a multi-servie organization responsive to the needs of seniors and thier families in Monterey County since 1970.
We are a county wide agency with two offices in Monterey and an office in Salinas. Call 1-800-510-2020 for services:
INFORMATION AND REFERALS:
Comprehensive information referrals to community agencies serving seniors.
Forms completion assistance problems solving and follow-up
Problem solving and follow-up
Monthly Money Management

TAX COUNCELING OF RHTE ELDERLY:
State and Federal Tax Preparation

HOMESHARING
Service-Exchanges and affordable shard living arrangements.

HEALTHE INSURANCE COUNCLING & ADVOCASY PROGRAM (HICAP)
Education on Medicare benefits 
Information and assistance for members of managed care systems

FRIENDLY VISITOR SUPPORT
Companionship 
Errands/Grocery shopping 
Transportation assistance
Telephone reassurance

SENIOR PEER COUNCELING
Emotional support for older adults experiencing grief and depression due to loss, loneliness, failing health and other stresses of ageing.

SENIOR EMPLOYMENT
Senior Aids: paid community service work for older workers in non-profit and governmental agencies.
Employment Specialists: matching seniors and employers in the private sector.
Assisting in computer training, and other work refresher skills.
projects:
We have a great need to establish information databases, currently for volunteers countywide. We can work with students to achieve specific goals, and create projects to fit both of our needs.
ESTABLISMENT OF VOLUNTEER DATABASE:
Unification of all volunteers in to one stream lined database for employee use, and outside volunteer registration. 
Easy to use database that holds all volunteers personal information regarding volunteer history, volunteer preferences, and interests for proper program placement.
Access to database from our website, for Board Members and outside project Managers.
Easy sorting, mailing lists and other information for us to use.

name: Alliance On Aging-Salinas Office.,Sr. Empl. Proj.
description: Opportunities for seniors.  Job retraining, Health Insurance Counseling, Homeshare, Inforamtion and referral for tax counseling.

name: The ALS Association Greater Bay Area Chapter
description:
The ALS Association is the only national not-
for- profit voluntary health organization dedicated solely to the fight against ALS through research, patient support, infomation dissemination and public awareness. Our mission is to lead the fight to cure and treat ALS through global cutting-edge research, and to empower people with Lou Gehrig's disease and their families to live fuller lives by providing them with compassionate care and support.

name: AMBAG Association of Monterey Bay Area Governments
description: AMBAG is a joint powers agency and a metropolitian planning organization for the Monterey Bay Area ( Monterey, Santa Cruz, and San benito Counties. AMBAG conducts planing programs focusing on water quality and transportation.

rescue.  Our goal is to relief overcrowded animal shelters thereby
reducing euthanasia.  However

Arts Council for Monterey County
description:
The Arts Council for Monterey County's mission is to improve the quality of life for everyone in Monterey County through the arts.

The Arts Council assists other arts organzations by providing grant opportunities as well as co-sponsor art festivals and opporunities for artists. Since 1988, the Arts Council for Monterey County has provided arts-based learning for children through our Professional artists in the schools prgram (PAS). We offer visual arts, dance, storytelling and theatre to 5,000 children yearly.

Our goals are to expand arts learning to areas in North and South County areas. The Arts Council also provides after school instruction and works hard to develop cutting edge curriculum that will help to integrate the arts with other disciplines.
projects:
1.  Financial Management intern

2.  Audience Development / Public Relations intern

3.  Mi Vida / Mi Planeta (My Life / My Planet) mixed media / multimedia installation at the Monterey Bay Aquarium (many community-based components)

name: Anzan High School
Auburn's House Montessori School
description: The Mission of Auburn's House is to create a warm, loving environment that welcomes the child. Each child takes ownership and feels a part of the school family. Children are honored for their individual personalities. Montessori educational practice helps children develop creativity, problem solving, social, and time-management skills, to contribute to society and the environment, and to become fulfilled persons in their particular time and place on Earth. The basis of Montessori practice in the classroom is respected individual choice of research and work, and uninterrupted concentration rather than group lessons led by an adult.

name: Carmel Bach Festival
description: The mission of the Carmel Bach Festival is to celebrate the genius of Johann Sebastian Bach, his contemporaries and musical heirs through performances and educational activities of the highest caliber.

name: Bay View Elementary
description: Bay view is a school of diverse cultures,languages, and family structures where everyone is important. Our parents and experienced staff work together to create a school climate of high standards that incorporates the various learning styles and abilities of our students. With many bilingual classes, extended-day Kindergarten classes, rich art and music programs, and a remarkable library program, Bay View students are able to shine!
projects: none at this time

name: Big Brothers Big Sisters
description: Our mission is to make a positive difference in the lives of children through relationship with caring volunteers who serve as role models, mentors and friends.  High School Bigs Program (HSBP) is an afterschool site based program administered by the Big Brother and Big Sister of Monterey County. HSBP recruits, enrolls and trains high school students, who are interested in mentoring a youth at a neighboring elementary school.  Currently, HSBP works collaboratively with Natividad Elementary and North Salinas High School as a means to operate its program.
projects: Please see BBBS program manager or HSBP coordinator.

name: Beacon House Residential Treatment Prog. for Addiction
description:
A drug and alcohol treatment program for adult men and women, 18 and older. A 12 Step based program that offers a comprehensive schedule for the discovery of addictive behaviors, guided by an expert staff
with many years of experience.      

A safe and comfortable home like setting, ,just  a few blocks from the Monterey Bay.

name: Big Sur Environmental Institute at Brazil Ranch
description:
The Big Sur Environmental Institute (BSEI) offers conservation forums on environmental conservation, stewardship and sustainability at the spectacular Brazil Ranch in Big Sur. Forums guide individuals, communities, business, and public agencies onto an ecologically, socially and economically sustainable path. 
 
Our Vision

People depend on the natural environment for water, food, fuel, shelter, medicine, open space and beauty. Many environmental problems respect no borders and threaten the health, prosperity and even the national security of nations. Addressing these problems and achieving sustainable, socially responsible management of natural resources ¿ local, nationally and globally ¿ requires leaders to find new ways to establish and share connections between people and places. Brazil Ranch is the point of convergence for this discussion.
projects:
Geographic Information Systems projects are of interest.

Programming for low-income, educationally underserved populations and group home residents.

Projects focusing on invasive vegetation and cliff sides.

name: Boys & Girls Clubs of Monterey County, Seaside Club
description: Our mission is to inspire and empower Monterey County youth to reach their full potential to become responsible healthy, productive and successful citizens. We strive to instill as sense of belonging, competence, usefulness and power and influence within our Members by providing positive role modeling, mentoring, individual, small group and large group youth development activities in the following areas: Recreation, Sports & Fitness, Education & Career Development, Arts, Character & Leadership Development, Health & Life Skills, Science & Technology.

name: Bradley Elementary School
description:
Vision Statement

All members of the Bradley School Community maintain that a collaborative spirit is essential to the pursuit of academic excellence.
 
We seek to provide a safe learning environment and a high quality program of instruction in which students effectively collaborate with their peers while learning to make choices and set personal goals for success. 

We acknowledge that a respectful environment in which students feel self-confident and proud of their work, results in a learning experience in which enjoyment, imagination, and independence flourish. Our program honors and values the diversity among us thereby enriching the learning experience.
 
We value seek to provide innovative programs to enhance and strengthen our curriculum which include technology , visual and performing arts, and a variety of enrichment opportunities.
 
We work in unison to support home-school-community activities through active communication, effective forums, educational opportunities, and participation in community service.
 
We value and recognize the contributions and input of every member of the Bradley School community as vital to our collective success.

name: Cabrillo College Teaching & Learning Center
American Cancer Society
description: The American Cancer Society is the nationwide community-based voluntary health organization dedicated to eliminating cancer as a major health problem by preventing cancer, saving lives, and diminishing suffering from cancer, through research, education, advocacy, and service.

name: American Cancer Society
description: The American Cancer Society is the nationwide community based voluntary health organization dedicated to eliminating cancer as a major health problem by preventing cancer, saving lives, and diminishing suffering from cancer through research, education, advocacy, and service.

name: Captain Cooper School
description: Captain Cooper School, a K-5 school nestled in the Santa Lucia Mountains of Big Sur, is located 26 miles south of Carmel on California State Route One. Surrounded by mountains, the school sits some 500 feet above the entrance to the Big Sur Valley.  Captain Cooper is the smallest elementary school in the Carmel Unified School District.  Our purpose is to enrich and educate students lives everyday with a cirriculum that includes but is not limited to general education, poetry, cultural activities, field trips, health fairs and an introduction to jazz music program.

description: K-5 Elementary School

name: Carmel Youth Center
address_street: SW Corner of Fourth Avenue and Torres Street
description: Our mission is to provide an after-school environment for the Youth of Carmel and its surrounding areas (Monterey, Big Sur, Cachagua and Pebble Beach) that provides postive role modeling, mentoring, individual and small group youth development activities in the following areas: Recreation, Education & Work Experience, Arts, Leadership Development, and Life Skills.
projects: There are opportunities for seniors of all majors to complete their capstones with the Carmel Youth Center - proposals are welcome.

name: Center for Community Advocacy
description: The Center for Community Advocacy (CCA) trains farmworkers to form and lead neighborhood-based tenant and health committees or comités that, themselves, advocate for improved housing and health conditions for farmworkers and other low-income families in Monterey County and Santa Cruz County.

name: Charles Armstrong School
description: Charles Armstrong School is the San Francisco Bay Area¿s independent elementary and middle school for students with language-based learning differences, such as dyslexia. Since 1968, CAS has helped thousands of students discover that learning can be a rewarding experience ¿ by helping them gain the reading, writing, speaking and/or math skills that eluded them in traditional schools.

name: Chartwell School
description: Since 1983, Chartwell School has been educating students with a wide range of visual and auditory language-based learning challenges in a way that provides the skills, confidence, and creativity to return successfully to mainstream education and enjoy learning throughout life.  The typical student enters Chartwell with academic performance two or more years below expected grade level, despite normal or better intelligence.  Here, what others see as problems, Chartwell sees as opportunities.  Our immediate goal is to guide children toward becoming healthy, curious, confident and appreciated learners again.
projects:
Test results from 1999-present reveal that students gain more than one full year in key basic skills in reading, writing, vocabulary, comprehension, and math for each year they are at Chartwell.  Many gain even more.  After an average of three years at Chartwell, students return to mainstream education as capable learners.  More than 75% of our students return to public schools. Chartwell estimates that more than 90% complete high school and 70% go on to college or other post-secondary learning.  These results are much higher than would ever have been predicted for this type of learner without successful intervention at Chartwell. 

  The roles of illiteracy and learning failure in juvenile crime, teen pregnancy, high school dropouts, childhood anxiety and depression, substance abuse, long-term welfare dependence, and adult incarceration are well documented.  Chartwell is determined to make a difference in these statistics. Chartwell  alumni often tell us, ¿You changed my life.¿

A capstone project could include developing and conducting an alumni survey via mail and email to further document the effectiveness of Chartwell's programs.

name: Community Human Services- Family to Family
description: Family to Family is a community based approach to change child welfare systems, most recently by advocating for more children to remain safely with their own families or a family-like connection. There are, however, emergency situations where out-of-home care is necessary. In these cases, the Family to Family program works to support children and families in navigating through the child welfare system. At its core, Family to Family applies four basic principles: A child's safety is paramount; Children belong in families; Families need strong communities; and Public child welfare systems need partnerships with the community and with other systems to achieve strong outcomes for children.

name: Neighborhood Services
description:
General purpose of Neighborhood Services:  To foster civic engagement in the City of Salinas.  
Currently, the City of Salinas City Council has authorized the following Neighborhood Services Work Plan components for Fiscal Year 2006/2007 and Fiscal Year 2007/2008:
A.  Implement a Neighborhood Engagement Strategy 
- Coordinate 2 general community meetings in each Council district per fiscal year.
- Coordinate 1 community cleanup in each Council district per fiscal year.
- Coordinate 2 community resource fairs across the City per fiscal year.
B.  Build a Community Network
-Engage neighborhood and community groups (small groups, nonprofits, school groups, religious, Neighborhood Watch) to initiate outreach and build city network and networking opportunities, while assessing available community resources
- Make use of networking opportunities to help build and promote youth activities and programs while developing a volunteer element
- Develop network to be multipurpose in scope and accessible by all departments
C.  Distribute the Neighborhood Problem Solver
- Completion of updates and language translations of information in Problem Solver
- Development of a training module for the Problem Solver
- Conduct initial trainings on use of Problem Solver for (existing) small groups, nonprofits, school groups, religious groups, and Neighborhood Watch groups
- Utilize Neighborhood Problem Solver in conjunction with Neighborhood Watch presentations
- Implement followup program to help determine effectiveness of training module and use of Problem Solver by trained groups
D.  Support the Community Safety Initiative
- Work with the Community Safety Director to coordinate Neighborhood Watch group meetings and presentations of the Neighborhood Problem Solver
- Assist Weed and Seed program with outreach design
- Collaborate with Youth Advisory Commission and Recreation-Park Department to organize a youth forum
- Coordinate other activities as may be required to support the Community Safety Plan
E.  Conducting Additional Support Activities
- Follow up on neighborhood issues and complaints
- Evaluate the VISTA program for an eventual pilot program on literacy
- Explore Adopt-a-Highway / Neighborhood / Park / Street programs (\ADOPT\")

name: Castroville Library Homework Center
description: Recognizing the cultural and linguistic diversity of our communities, the staff of the Monterey County Free Libraries provides free access to information, educational, and recreational materials and lifelong learning opportunities. PS99
projects: Castroville is a small agricultural town but growing. The population is 85% Latino with a mix of long time residents and newer immigrants, mostly from Mexico. There are a number of large families, giving the sense that almost everyone is related. There are strong ties to specific parts of Mexico where many families came from and still have relatives. The population of Castroville is also young, with about half of the residents under 21. The town would be a good site for GIS mapping, studies of changing attitudes among immigrants, immigration research, educational research, language acquisition studies, research on farmworker issues, etc. Near Castroville there is a park with a nature preserve that is home to some rare and endangered plants. Environmentally oriented students could be involved in work to preserve native plants and control invasive species. I will be happy to discuss your project with you and put you in touch with local people who might be able to help you (mands@redshift.com). One project for Spanish students could be to track kids as they go into college; put together a book of their university application personal statements, and translate it into spanish so that their parents can read it.

name: California Rural Legal Assistance (CRLA)
description: California Rural Legal Assistance, Inc. (CRLA) provides free legal assistance to low-income people in twenty-one California communities, including Monterey, Salinas, Watsonville, Gilroy and Santa Cruz. Our organization was founded over 40 years ago to provide legal services to farm workers. Since then we have expanded our work. We currently assist farm workers and other low-income persons in these five priority areas: 1) Labor and employment, 2) Housing, 3) Education, 4) Civil rights, and 5) Family security, such as public benefits.

name: Soledad Mission (Nuestra Senora de la Soledad) - Diocese of Monterey
description: Mission Nuestra Senora Dolorosisima de la Soledad, thirteenth in the chain of Alta California missions, was established on October 9, 1791, at the site of an Esselen Indian village recorded by Pedro Font as Chuttusgelis. Presently the mission is part of the Catholic Parish of Soledad but since 1835, there has not been a priest served at the mission on a regular basis. Services are held four times a year on designated days. The gardens and a small museum is open to the public. Further restoration is being conducted as funds become available. The continued restoration and maintenance of Soledad Mission is made possible by donations of those who cherish California's rich heritage. Soledad Mission is sustained through donations from individuals, proceeds from the gift shop, and money raised at the two annual fund-raisers, a June Barbecue and a Fall Fiesta.
