<h4 class=\"MsoNormal\"><span style=\"font-family: Georgia;\">Since December 2005
status: the Women Alive Program is committed

name: to women living on the streets. We provide an emergency overnight shelter and
hospitality center
status: where homeless women can have dinner

name: laundry
status: take a deep breath from the life in the streets and spend the night in

name: a safe
status: non-judgmental and nurturing space. This is the only no-questions-asked

name:
emergency walk-in shelter for street women in Monterey County.

The Women Alive! Program is located in Dorothy's Place Hospitality Center
the Dayroom area. Every day
status: our Dayroom closes at 2:00 p.m. for cleaning and

name: transformation into the Women Alive! Shelter. Homeless women may enter from
7:00-8:30 every night and stay until 6:30 in the morning.
Following the Franciscan tradition of unconditional
love and peace
status: this emergency shelter not only seeks to provide a safe roof to

name: homeless women but also to validate their human and loving capacity to engage
in constructive attitudes.  We aim
to offer them some stabilization based on companionship and gentleness.
<h4 class=\"MsoNormal\"><span style=\"font-family: Georgia;\">The women who come to this shelter have many
opportunities to share meals
status: safe sleeping space and engage in conversations

name: that support their dreams and efforts to move forward with their lives!
We can say that the real gift of the shelter  is the daily re-discovery of life and opportunities.
<h4 class=\"MsoNormal\"><span style=\"font-family: Georgia;\">We understand that being homeless is first a
reality of aloneness and soul hunger.  Therefore
status: it’s a blessing to witness distraught women receive the

name: chance for a safe deep breath; how a smile slowly come to their faces
with the slow dawning realization that they are no longer alone.
<h4 class=\"MsoNormal\"><span style=\"font-family: Georgia;\">Because of that
status: we provide homeless women with a

name: space where they can cultivate nurturing feelings and sense of well-being.
We constantly seek for new and better ways to communicate
help them to face daily challenges
to their impaired conditions.  Opening
our doors for women at night constantly amaze us. We have discovered that being
‘an instrument of peace’ not only feels really good but it’s constructive and
self-developing!
How You Can Help!
<h4 class=\"MsoNormal\"><span style=\"font-family: Georgia;\">You can help keeping the Women Alive! shelter open
every night. We are blessed to get resources from individual donors and responsible
citizens from the Salinas community as well as from grants from United Way
Monterey County

name: El Pajaro Community Development Corporation
description:
El Pajaro Community Development Corporation was formed in 1978 with the mission of ¿Promoting equal access to economic opportunity. Since its inception, El Pajaro CDC has focused on developing micro-enterprises and small businesses. The organization has successfully assisted hundreds of small businesses with technical assistance, loans, business plans, marketing, management, business technology applications and accounting/bookkeeping.  One of El Pajaro CDC¿s hallmark projects is Plaza Vigil, which was built in 1996, and is one of the few retail business incubators in the U. S. and perhaps the only one serving Latinos. Plaza Vigil has always been a vibrant community resource located in the heart of Watsonville¿s downtown.   El Pajaro CDC acts as the micro-enterprise development partner for Childcare Ventures, a child care outreach, education and business development project providing assistance to Latino, monolingual family childcare providers. El Pajaro CDC has also fostered the creation of the Watsonville Childcare Providers Association with membership of 55 women that manage their own businesses at home. During the FY06/07 El Pajaro CDC served 588 clients, from those 67% percent were women and 95% percent were Hispanic. Some of El Pajaro CDC¿s major accomplishments for FY06/07 include the following: 
El Pajaro CDC was able to exceed its goals in terms of number of hours and number of current and prospective businesses that received services. This was possible thanks to the establishment of partnerships that allowed El Pajaro CDC to leverage new funds and resources. 

El Pajaro CDC was able to exceed its goals in terms of number of hours and number of current and prospective businesses that received services. This was possible thanks to the establishment of partnerships that allowed El Pajaro CDC to leverage new funds and resources. 

One-on-one technical assistance. With assistance from the Appleton grant and other funds, El Pajaro CDC provided over 1369 hours of bilingual technical assistance to Watsonville and Pajaro Valley residents, including assistance to 14 Plaza Vigil Business Incubator Merchants and the Plaza Vigil Merchants association, Small Farmers, Family Childcare Providers and Cal Works Clients. This included clients that attended training and one-on one counseling sessions.

Training. - A total of 123 hours of training were provided to 288 current and prospective business owners in the Watsonville and Pajaro Valley area. Trainings provided by El Pajaro CDC included Business Plan Training workshops for new entrepreneurs, small farmer and the Plaza Vigil¿s Incubator tenants.

Micro-lending: Thanks to the funds granted by the Appleton Foundation our organization was able to renew The Community Partnership Loan Program with the Santa Cruz Community Credit Union and increase the total amount of the Revolving Loan fund. El Pajaro CDC initially had $11K in available for lending. During the past year, the loan fund was increased to $50K. El Pajaro CDC used the $14K granted by the Appleton Foundation for this purpose and additional $25K that El Pajaro CDC deposited from el Pajaro CDC¿s reserve. This decision made by El Pajaro CDC¿s shows the commitment that this organization has to its organizational mission of ¿Promoting equal access to economic opportunity.¿ In addition to this, The Santa Cruz Community Credit Union is matching the fund 2:1. Therefore, the total amount available for loan is $100K. El Pajaro CDC considers this a tremendous success and continues seeking funds to increase the loan fund.
projects:
Market Research for Plaza Vigil Incubator Program

Plaza Vigil Incubator Clients Business Plans

Harvey House and Railroad Museum
description: The purpose of the non-profit foundation is to utilize its unique asset (the first mayor's house) to provide the community with a snapshot of family life in an agricultural town of the 1870's and to tell the story of transportation and the development of the Salinas Valley.  Specifically, our purpose is to support the teaching of history and social studies in Monterey County schools.  In the next year, we intend to complete renovation of the education center and begin our educational programs.

name: Food Bank for Monterey County
description: The Food Bank for Monterey County is committed \to lead efforts in the awareness and elimination of hunger in Monterey County\". We provide an efficient
projects: centralized system for collecting and distributing food that reduces waste and alleviates hunger in Monterey County. We also solicit donations of food
issues: and distribute emergency and supplemental food to needy people and local charities."

name: Forest Theater Guild
projects: The Guild is a community service organization dedicated to building stronger communities through theater. Our program provides the following suggested opportunities for a capstone project: 1) The All-Star Program fills an important gap in public education for providing standards-based live performing arts experiences to county youth. The program meets several goals, including, but not limited to the following: 1) Enhances cross cultural communication for our youth; 2) Exposes under served youth to live performing arts; 3) Builds audience diversity; and 4)Strengthens collaborations in the arts community. A capstone project should/could consider the importance of live performing arts education to youth, particularly to those in under served communities, in preventing increased gang association, violence and drop-outs. Moreover, research indicates that there's an inequity in the availability of arts to students with wealthier, higher performing schools receiving the resources for arts education, while lower performing schools are denied it. A student project could investigate the differences in our school districts county-wide, track the patterns of violence in our community, and provide valuable information to educators and administrators alike. Another suggested option would be to measure the impact of the performing arts experience on the participants. The evaluative study could measure changes in attitudes and cultural perceptions, reading comprehension, self confidence, leadership skills, and appreciation of the literature and the ability of the students to apply it to other disciplines. 2)Graphic Design and Marketing: A capstone project could investigate the value of marketing for a small non-profit. It would consider multiple approaches to successful brand identity and tailored marketing to diverse audiences. The research could/would identify a need for a diversified approach, identify new audiences and develop key messages, create new avenues for effective and affordable advertising, and provide a cost/benefit analysis of marketing for small non-profit organizations. Finally, the special project would measure the success of the promotion in terms of increased visibility for the organization, ticket and box office sales, increased membership and individual donations, and greater awareness of the Forest Theater Guild and its legacy in the community. 3)F.T. Renner Student Short Film Festival: A Capstone project would be in project management. This intern will be taking the concept and implementing the expanded program from beginning to end. This would include initial research into the various film schools, finding sponsors, selecting the films, working with local screen writers and directors, promoting the event, working with selected vendors, and coordinating the event. In addition to working with the executive director, the interns will also be mentored by Dr. Barbara Mossberg, a professor who teaches service learning and Hamish Tyler, Administrator for the Arts of Monterey County Office of Education and High School teacher with 32 years of teaching experience.

name: Gavilan College Small Business Development Center
description: Our mission is to provide business owners and managers with information, training and expert individual consulting.  Gavilan College Small Business Development Center was established to meet the specialized needs of the small business community of the Gavilan College District, including Gilroy, Morgan Hill, San Benito County, and Monterey County (east of the Salinas river).

Girl Scouts of California's Central Coast
description:
Girl Scouting builds girls of courage, confidence and character who make the world a better place. 
Central coast living provides a richness which when added to the Girl Scout program creates options only limited by the girls themselves in choosing and designing activities that follow their interests and dreams. From fitness in rock climbing, soccer and surfing to art and mural design, girls are presented with a multitude of options. Plus, by tapping into scientific and marine biology resources and the mosaic of cultures, food and music to be found in the local region, girls acquire understanding and growth in knowledge.

Just as the geography of the three counties is diverse, so are its communities and residents. Since its inception, Girl Scouts of the Monterey Bay has taken responsibility to be a community resource, leading as well as collaborating to create outreach programs in migrant camps and other non-traditional settings, and tackling such contemporary issues as teen parenthood, drugs and alcohol.
projects:
Marketing: Identify marketing techniques to increase Latino parent participation in communities. 
Management: Help co-manage a Service Unit that contains 100 troops or more. Would develop SL student administrative skills such as budgeting, marketing, human resources and much more.
Community Outreach: Create and deliver short and long term programs to low income girls and Julietes (girls without a troop).
Recruit/Event Planning: Assisting Service Units with event planning that deal with recruitment.

name: Girls Inc of the Centeral Coast
description:
The mission of Girls Incorporated is to inspire all girls to be strong, smart and bold, to respect themselves and the world around them.

Girls Incorporated of the Central Coast is an affiliate of the Girls Incorporated national organization, the nation's leading research and evaluation organization on issues pertaining to girls and young women.  We work with girls ages 9 to 18 with proven \girl-focused\" programs at our outreach sites established at schools throughout Monterey County.  Girls Inc. of the Central Coast has grownn to serve over 900 girls in 20 schools in 6 cities.  In the future
population_size: we plan to offer our programs in San Benito and Santa Cruz counties.

name: The oldest girl-centered organization in the United States
status: Girls Inc. has been transforming girls' views of themselves and their opportunities for generations.  Girls Inc. of the Central Coast is much more than an after school program
address_street:
we are the place and have the people to help girls succeed.

name: Green Acres Elementary School
description:
Public education of Pre-K through 5th grade students in the Live Oak School District of Santa Cruz, Ca
Green Acres is the original site of a National Science gardening program called Life Lab.

Green Acres has achieved the California Distinguished School status honor.

Green Acres is a Trianing site for the National recognized Literacy program Reading Recovery.

Green Acres is a host site for a diverse field of educational technolgy training.

Green Acres is a literacy qualified school with a program called Breakthrough to Literacy.

The Greenfield Union School District is a child-centered District, committed to preparing its diverse student population with a quality education and providing the support necessary to maximize student's potential so that they become life-long learners and positive contributors to our global society.

name: Good Shepherd Catholic School
description: An inter-parish school that commits itself to excellence in education throug hthe creation of a nurturing and stimulating enviornment that embraces and proclaims religious, academic, social, physical and aesthetic values.

name: Guitars Not Guns
description:
Guitars Not Guns provide guitars and lessons to foster kids, at risk youth and other children in a classroom setting with qualified teachers.  Each student is assigned a beginner guitar when they come to the first class.  They are allowed to take their guitars home with them and are asked to pracitce 30 minutes each day.

Classrooms are donated locations and teacher are all volunteers.  Volunteers are required to have a background check.   Level 1 books are printed and made to fit Guitars Not Guns program with consideration of where each student needs to begin.

Many students have been abused and may have low self-esteem.  By learning to play the guitar it may help build self esteem and teach confidence.

Hartnell College
description: Hartnell College provides the leadership and resources to ensure that all students shall have equal access to a quality education and the opportunity to pursue and achieve their goals. We are responsive to the learning needs of our community and dedicated to a diverse educational and cultural campus environment that prepares our students for productive participation in a changing world.

name: Cerra Vista Elementary School
description:
K-5 Elementary School.
Our mission is to provide a meaningful challenging curriculum within a nurturing and safe environment, enabling ALL children to become lifetime achievers and respectful, responsible citizens.

name: Health Improvement Partnership

name: LUPE Central Coast - La Union del Pueblo Entero
description:
LUPE, La Union del Pueblo Entero, is a non-profit organization that seeks to improve the quality of life for farm worker, Latino and immigrant communities throughout rural California.

In 1989, honored civil rights and labor leader Cï¿½sar E. Chï¿½vez founded La Uniï¿½n del Pueblo Entero to focus on the needs and problems that Latino immigrants and farm workers encounter daily, such as overwhelming poverty rates, indecent housing and living conditions, and unjust access to health care.  Cï¿½sar realized that workers had needs beyond the work place.  Although Cï¿½sar founded a labor union through the United Farm Workers (UFW), these other needs could best be addressed through the creation of organizations such as LUPE to address the indignities specifically beyond the workplace.  LUPE is not a labor union and is a separate and distinct 501(c)(3) organization.  

Today, LUPE has operations in three states that include California, Texas and Arizona.  Nationally, LUPEï¿½s programs demonstrate a track record of effective leadership development.  LUPE provides an array of services from its offices in a three-state regions.  These services include:

ï‚§	Leadership development and community organizing programs
ï‚§	U.S. Citizenship classes
ï‚§	Literacy programs
ï‚§	English as a Second Language (ESL) programs	
ï‚§	General Equivalency Diploma (GED) courses
ï‚§	Income tax preparation and assistance
ï‚§	Immigration forms preparation
ï‚§	Notary Services
ï‚§	Discounts & benefits to LUPE members

LUPE has developed experience with community service and outreach over the last 16 years.  LUPE in California has utilized their experiences over those years and the experience of the Farm Worker Movement.  The strength of LUPE is found within our leaders, volunteers and staff that build the organization through house meeting after house meeting, committee after committee, campaign after campaign.  LUPE committees respond to the injustices facing farm worker and immigrant communities. Most of our focus during this time has been on specific needs in farm worker communities as they emerge.

name: MCOE -  BTOP/Media Center for Art, Tech
description:
In October 2010 the Central Coast Broadband Consortium Public Computing Alliance, led by the Monterey County Office of Education (MCOE) and its Media Center for Art, Education and Technology (MCAET), received a Federal stimulus grant, called “BTOP” (Broadband Technology Opportunities Program) to increase computer and digital media literacy in Monterey County’s underserved rural communities.

 

With this grant the Central Coast Broadband Consortium Public Computing Alliance created the program Conexión Comunitaria to provide free technology classes including basic computer and internet skills, word processing, animation, web design, digital photography, audio and video production, and more.

 

Conexión Comunitaria partners are building, updating, and equipping public computing centers throughout the region, including a state-of-the-art mobile technology classroom, and offers classes on a regular basis. Conexión Comunitaria serves all of Monterey County, with a particular emphasis on providing workshops throughout the Salinas Valley — from Salinas to King City.

 

Participants are learning new skills that are helpful to them in school and in the workplace. Classes are offered in English, Spanish, and several indigenous Oaxacan languages.

 

The first training schedule became available to the public in March 2011, and the formal launching of the mobile technology classroom will soon follow. Many classes are offered in the evenings and on weekends in order to maximize access for everyone, and all classes are completely free of charge to participants.
projects: Program evaluation of program.  Digital literacy date in Monterey County.  Research projects about lives of participants/workforce development in relation to BTOP Programs.

Education and Prevention: High-risk individuals (i.e. homeless, injection drug users, their partners, drug users and sex workers) and all other individuals throughout Monterey County.
projects: Provide education and outreach to people in the community regarding HIV and AIDS through the C.H.O.W. program. There may also be opportunities with the Women's Outreach Program, Latino Outreach Program, Gay Teen Alliance, or Man to Man Program, or planning social events for youth ages 7-15 infected by or affected by HIV / AIDS. name: Boronda Community School - MCOE Alternative EducationProgram
description: The mission of the Alternative Education Program of the Monterey County Office of Education is to prepare students for future success by providing a supportive school environment that focuses on increasing academic and pro-social behaviors and skills, while providing functional life skills instruction. We respect and value the unique contributions of each of our students and our role in assisting them in becoming responsible, stable, and contributing members of society. We work to create a supportive learning environment for students who have been expelled from local school districts, have been detained in the county juvenile facilities, or who are otherwise at risk for academic failure. Our programs are unique because of the students we serve. Small classes and individualized approaches meet the needs of each student.
projects: 1. Video documentary about Rancho Cielo facility - CSUMB students could teach Boronda students in filming, editing and create a documentary about the experience of youth at this facility. 2. Video documentary about the Global Citizenship component of the Alternative Education Department. Because many of the Boronda students have not left Salinas or been exposed to other areas across the state, country or world, the program takes its students on field trips to open their minds to a new world. It is often a transformative experience for the youth.

description:
Built to serve as a public school and town meeting hall, Colton Hall is now a museum and is open for public viewing.

California's first Constitution was drafted in this historic site in October, 1849. Colton Hall is a landmark in the City of Monterey, once the Capital of Alta California.

Monterey Museum of Art
description: At the Monterey Museum of Art you will see California and the Central Coast through the eyes of artists. The museum's exceptional collections, exhibitions, and educational programs reflect the unique cultural heritage of the region and its distinctive influence within the cultural community. The museum's permanent collection includes California paintings, sculpture, works on paper and photography, Asian art, international folk art, and features significant bodies of work by Armin Hansen, William Ritschel, Ansel Adams, and Edward Weston.

name: Museum of Monterey (formerly Monterey History and Maritime Museum)
description: The Museum of Monterey is dedicated to being a leader in models of history and social studies education and a regional leader in educational programming. Therefore, the Museum will implement an array of education-centered programs including outreach, and special events. Programs will engage the community in innovative and dynamic ways while providing opportunities for life-long learning. To support these goals, the Museum is committed to the creation of a strong educational program with an infrastructure that supports effective services. We intend to increase the potential for visual and historic literacy, creativity, and critical thinking skills. Topically, the Museum of Monterey will focus on the Monterey Bay as a community tied to the land and inspire the appreciation for the beauty and complexity of its rich history.

orientation sessions
status: please refer to the Monterey Peninsula Unified School

name: District profile in the MySLP: https://myslp.csumb.edu/partners/view/2902

orientation.

Del Rey Woods Elementary School provides a standards- based
status: integrated curriculum with a focus on literacy
address_city: multicultural diversity and global awareness.  Equal access to the core curriculum and appropriate interventions are ensured for all learners.  Staff
address_state: parents and community members are committed to instill a love for learning in each child.  Students develop self-esteem and high expectations for themselves to grow up into responsible
description: educated citizens.

description: sans-serif;\">One change MPUSD has initiated for spring orientation is that all students
projects: sans-serif;\"> have their TB test report or X-Ray clearance at the time of their orientation.  Student will no longer be allowed to turn in their TB test results at a later time.

address_state: sans-serif;\">In order to expedite the TB testing process and ensure students have their TB test to begin their placement hours on time
address_zip: we were able to obtain assigned TB test days.  During these assigned days students will be scheduled every 3 minutes rather than 15-30 minute regular appointment.

name: We are a fairly small school with approximately 400 students in grades K-5. Our students come from diverse cultural backgrounds and often speak English as their second language. We celebrate this diversity. You will find our school has a very welcoming feel to it. The staff is friendly and the students are generally very polite and respectful. We encourage people to volunteer who are conscientious
description: Elementary School

name: George C. Marshall Elementary School MPUSD
description:
Education of elementary aged children.

This school site requires a Monterey Peninsula Unified School District orientation and clearance.  This process is a new one as of Fall 2011. 

For information regarding dates, times and locations of orientation sessions, please refer to the Monterey Peninsula Unified School District profile in the MySLP: https://myslp.csumb.edu/partners/view/2902

No placements at this school will be possible without an orientation.

If you have any questions please contact Aline Sanchez, alsanchez@csumb.edu or (831) 582-4184.

name: Manzanita Elementary School
projects:
Researcher - One is for checking stores and the internet for prices when we are preparing grant proposals. Also a teacher may have a topic where she needs more information, i.e. common plants from colonial days.  Information that is available form the library/internet. 
Fund Raiser - We need help with rummage sales we hold periodically to raise funds for the school garden.  
     - writing grant proposals.  
     - securing donations from various resources  
     - developing new fundraising possibilities.

status: \"sans-serif\";\">If you have any questions please contact Aline Sanchez

name: Martin Luther King Jr. Academy is a public school serving grades 3
address_city: 7 and 8 within the Seaside community.   The Under the Big Top After School Program is designed to serve the physical
address_zip: intellectual and social needs of young adolescents.

name: Students at this stage of life demonstrate a significant diversity in rates of growth and maturity.  Most students between the ages of 11 and 14 are undergoing the following changes - social maturation
address_street: growth in importance of peer relationships
address_city: and development of norms and values.

name: These physical
address_street: emotional and social changes do not always occur easily or smoothly.  Early adolescence has traditionally been a time of difficulty.  For this reason
address_street2: it has been suggested that students in this age range be educated in an environment that addresses and eases the transition from childhood to full adolescence.  The goal of the Under the Big Top After School Program is to provide a safe and nurturing environment where students are active learners in academic and enrichment opportunity classes.

name: Program Schedule:
3:30-4:25  Academic Support Class
4:25-4:45  Snack (provided by program)
4:45-5:45  Enrichment Club
5:45-6:00  Bus pick-up and student departure
How our program works:

Each student is enrolled in an Academic Support class for the first hour of the program from 3:30-4:25.  Tutors help students finish their homework and check for comprehension and accuracy.  Students who are finished with homework have the opportunity to work on one of our hands on activities focusing on Math
address_street: Language Arts and Social Studies concepts & skills.  This gives students a chance to apply what they have learned during the school day.

name: Enrichment Clubs are held during the second hour of the program from 4:45-5:45.  Each month
status: students are able to enroll in the Enrichment Club of their choice.  We offer 4-5 different Clubs per month-long \"Session\".  Examples of Clubs we have offered are: Drama
description: Science
projects: Singing
column17: much more!  Enrichment Clubs are a reward for students and an opportunity for them to learn life skills and develop personal interests.

name: Our goal is to make learning fun and relevant to the lives of our students.  We do this by turning academic concepts into hands-on activities.  With the decrease in the variety of elective classes offered during the school day
status:
our program tries to fill in those gaps and balance academics with enrichment opportunities.

"
address_street2: There are so many opportunities for capstone projects at our site! We are open to all of your ideas. Specific needs and ideas will be posted periodically.

description: Middle School|Government

name: Monterey Regional Waste Management District
Monterey Bay Reg. Waste Mgmt. Dist.-Small Planet Ed. Prog.
description: To provide the highest quality cost efficient integrated waste management services to the greater Monterey Peninsula while preserving our environment and protecting the public health through the reduction , reuse, recycling and safe disposal of our waste stream.
projects:
Last Chance Mercantile salvaging recyclables from incoming trash, a large scale composting program, and the Small Planet Garden - an educational resource for visiting school tours.
Ed. Materials for Small Planet Elemnentary School Program.
Develop New Native Plant Exhibit in Small Planet Garden.
Development of Traveling Solar Exhibit.

name: Monterey Regional Water Pollution Control Agency
description: In 1972, MRWPCA was formed to seek joint solutions to the wastewater treatment needs of its members: Del Rey Oaks, Monterey, Pacific Grove,Salinas, Sand City, Seaside, boronda, Castroville, Moss Landing, unincorporated areas of north Monterey County and Marina. MRWPCA is governed by a Board of directors representing each of the jurisdictions that it serves.
projects: Develop High school curriculum and classroom presentations.

name: Multiple Sclerosis Quality of Life Program
description: MSQLP provides case management services to clients with multiple sclerosis. Provides linkages to agencies, advocacy for clients with physicians, pharmaceutical companies, et. help with various psychosocial issues (finances, housing, equipment, etc.) education and support groups.

name: Monterey Rape Crisis Center
description: to advocate for sexual assault victims and to prevent sexual violence in the community through public education.  Services include 24 hour crisis line, 24 hour advocacy services (hospital, police, courts), individual and group counseling, outreach, and education.
projects: We have capstone opportunities for students in Collaborative Health and Human Services, HCOM, MIE, SBS, TMAC, TAT. We can tailor opportunites to MLOs.
issues: Advocacy|Health & Human Services|Social Services|Violence Prevention|Women's Issues

name: Museums of Los Gatos
description: The Museums of Los Gatos is a non profit educational institution dedicated to enhancing community life through the preservation, exhibition, and interpretation of our regional history, and in incresing community appreciation of fine arts. Established in 1965, the Los Gatos Museums Association includes the Art Museum of Los Gatos, the History Museum at Forbes Mill, and the Los Gatos Museums Gallery.

name: M.V. Foundation
description: Eradicate Child Labor.
issues: Advocacy|Before/After School|Community/Economic Development|Education|Health & Human Services|Housing & Homelessness|Labor|Literacy|Nutrition/Fitness|Violence Prevention|Women's Issues|Youth Development

name: National Alliance for the Mentally Ill Monterey County (NAMI)
description:
NAMI is dedicated to the eradication of mental illnesses and to the improvement of the quality of life of all whose lives are affected by these diseases.

Dedicated NAMI members, leaders, and friends work tireless across all levels to meet a shared NAMI mission of support, education, advocacy, and research for people living with mental illness through various activities.
projects: Open to ideas.
issues: Advocacy|Health & Human Services|Social Services|Substance Abuse|Violence Prevention

name: Natividad Medical Center - Volunteer Auxiliary
description: To assist with patient care/service at Natividad Medical Center. Volunteers help us meet the needs of patients. The Auxiliary operates a gift shop in the lobby of the Barnet J. Segal Outpatient Services Center. Volunteers help in numerous ways, including assisting visitors around the medical center campus, assembling baby gift bags for new mothers, offering companionship to pediatric and elderly patients and providing clerical and translation services. Volunteers are assigned according to their interests and skills.
projects: Patient escort desk, patient satisfaction survey compilation, transportation aide, patient advocate, special events. CAB S99.

name: Natividad Medical Center, Archer Child Advocacy Center
description: The Child Advocacy Center provides forensic interviews and medical-legal examinations of child sexual abuse victims in Monterey County.  Exams including gathering evidence at the request of law enforcement, medical screening exam to rule out abuse, and coordination of the Child Abuse.

name: Natividad Medical Center - Social Serv. Dept.
description: NMC is an inpatient meidcal facility serving all groups in Monterey County, majority of patients are indigent. Social workers conduct psychosocial assessments regarding child and elder abuse, domestic violence, substance abuse, etc. Services include crisis intervention, counseling, and referrals and grief and loss work.
issues: Health & Human Services|Housing & Homelessness|Social Services|Substance Abuse|Violence Prevention|Women's Issues

name: National Coalition Building Institute (NCBI)
description: The National Coalition Building Institute (NCBI) is a nonprofit leadership training organization based in Washington, D.C. Since 1984, NCBI has been working to eliminate prejudice and intergroup conflict in communities throughout the world. NCBI's proactive approach begins with a corps of community leaders who are taught effective bridge-building skills to combat intergroup conflicts. The local leadership team embodies all sectors of the community, including elected officials, law enforcement officers, government workers, educators, students, business executives, labor union leaders, community activists, and religious leaders. These community leaders work together as a resource team, offering prevention-oriented programs to deal with prejudice and intergroup tensions. Using NCBI tools for working through tough, polarizing intergroup issues, the leadership team is available to intervene in a community when specific intergroup conflicts arise.

name: New Families Inc.
address_street: PO Box 482-6062 Graham Hill Rd. Ste. D
description: New Families is a non-profit foster family agency with a goal of sustaining placements by providing support to the family and youth. Agency provides trainings, guidance, case management services and works with Santa Cruz, Monterey, San Benito and Santa Cruz counties.

name: North County Recreation and Park District
description: to provide safe and enriching recreation opportunities to the youth  (K-12) of North Monterey County

name: Cebrowski Institute
description:
The Cebrowski Institute

Our Mission:

The Cebrowski Institute for Innovation and Information Superiority sponsors cross-discipline projects leading to innovations that strengthen global security in the information age. 

Who we are: 

The Cebrowski Institute helps in a world dominated by distributed communication networks. Founded in 2002 as one of three inaugural institutes at the Naval Postgraduate School, the Institute operates as a network of research centers and projects serving a broad community of students and faculty. Our concentrations:


-Hastily Formed Networks (HFN) 
-Network Centric Operations (NCO) 
-Worldwide Consortium for the Grid (W2COG) 
-Autonomous Coordination 
-Mobile Devices and Communications 
-Information Operations 
-Counterterrorism and Irregular Warfare 
-Information Assurance and Security
projects:
We are hosting a Rebooting Computing Summit on Jan. 12th-14th, 2009. This is an invitational summit of 200 visionary leaders from all sectors touched by computing, including science, engineering, industry, business, education, journalism, policy-making, and government. We will create projects and form teams that will seed, nurture, and cultivate new ideas in the community. We will cross international borders. We will aggressively publicize the message of the wonder of computer science and the hope for the future. 
This is not a paper-presentation or inspiring-orations summit. This is a get-it-done summit. We will roll up our sleeves and work for three days to bring each of our most creative ideas forward and let them loose to innovate in our community. We are not trying to achieve a consensus around any one idea: we want to unleash many ideas. Using the Appreciative Inquiry process, professional facilitators will guide us to this outcome.
We are looking for several students from CSUMB that could attend the 3-day event to video-tape and take pictures throughout the summit. We would ask that they provide the equipment and upload the photos and video to our website each evening.  We would provide food and accomodations for the students.

name: Ohlone Elementary School
description:
Elementary school grades K-5.
At Ohlone School, we value the linguistic and cultural diversity of our learning community. We treat one another with respect. We prepare students for a lifetime of learning by providing a standards-based curriculum and by maintaining high expectations for student achievement. In a collaborative environment, teachers analyze student work and plan lessons to meet the needs of all learners. Staff and parents participate as partners in our students¿ education through workshops, meetings and frequent home/school communications. As members of the Ohlone community, we take responsibility for our actions and learning.

name: Mission San Juan Bautista - Diocese of Monterey
description: The town San Juan Baustista takes its name from the old Mission.  This Catholic Mission is part of the Catholic Diocese of Monterey and has the largest church of any of the Missions.  Its architecture and beauty are the best.  The Mission is maintained very well and has an unbroken succession of pastors from its original Missions.

name: Oldtown Salinas Association
description:
Established in 1977, the Oldtown Salinas Association is a non-profit business organization that promotes and enhances Oldtown Salinas through revitalization programs, marketing, business recruitment, community events, and advocacy with local government.

OSA is over 400 businesses strong, and truly is ï¿½The Heart of the Valley.ï¿½  OSA is led by a 16-member Board of Directors, and staffed by a professional, full-time Executive Director.

As a business improvement district, OSAï¿½s business-owner membership is assessed annually in order to promote and support the improvement of Oldtown Salinas. OSAï¿½s annual Program of Work is developed by the Board of Directors, and implemented by committees and staff.  The 2005-06 Program of Work focuses on business advocacy, marketing, landscape improvements and ensuring the safety and security of the Oldtown district.

An important fact about the Oldtown Salinas Association is that with the exception of staff, the organization is entirely voluntary.  The businesses determine the ultimate direction of OSA.  The Board of Directors hires an Executive Director to carry out the directive of the committees, oversee the budget, and to maintain relationships with City entities, other community organizations, the media and members.

OSA Committees
OSA committees include:  Holiday Parade of Lights, Marketing, Oldtown Foundation, Oldtown Salinas Marketplace, Oldtownï¿½s Passport to Cherryï¿½s, Parking and Security.

name: Monterey County Workforce Investment Board & VITA Sites
description: The Monterey County Workforce Investment Board (WIB) oversees the Montery County One Stop Career Centers and maintains service agreements with 16 local partners throughout Motnerey County. The Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA) program provides free tax preparation with a focus on Earned Income Tax Credit and Child Tax Credit for Lower individuals and familes.

name: Pacific Grove Heritage Society
description: To honor and tell the story of the diverse populations of Pacific Grove's history.
projects: Unknown at this time.

name: Pacific Oaks Childcare Center
description: Pre-School, Child Care.  Providing pre-school lessons.
projects: n/a

name: Performing Arts Center, San Luis Obispo
description: The Performing Arts Center, San Luis Obispo is a state-of-the-art performance facility located on the beautiful Central Coast of California at the campus of California Polytechnic State University (Cal Poly). Open since September of 1996, the Performing Arts Center incorporates two main venues: the Christopher Cohan Center, including the majestic 1,289-seat Sidney Harman Hall, the 180-seat classroom Philips Hall, and the multi-purpose Pavilion that holds various capacities up to 400 people; and the 498-seat Alex & Faye Spanos Theatre.

name: "
Monterey County Reads/Panetta Institute
description:
NOTE:  See individual school sites on the MySLP database and register your placement with Monterey County Reads at that site.

As a reading volunteer, you will work in a local elementary school, reading one-to-one with a kindergarten through thrid grade child in a supervised setting for 20-30 minutes per child; be a positive reading role model to a child who is having difficulty reading; get to know the interests of the child, talk to the child about these interests and  motivate the child to read on his or her own; and keep records of your sessions with the child's progress and give to the teacher.

name: Orange Grove Presbyterian - Disaster Assistance
description:
Disaster assistance working with those affected by Hurricane Katrina.
Presbyterian Disaster Assistance enables congregations and mission partners of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A) to witness to the healing love of Christ through caring for communities adversely affected by crisis and catastrophic events.
issues: Community/Economic Development|Health & Human Services|Housing & Homelessness|Public Safety

name: Monterey Peace and Justice Center
description: Monterey Peace and Justice Center seeks to promote coalition-building with environmental, human rights and labor groups to promote a culture of peace and justice in our own community and the world. Monterey Peace and Justice Center is a community resource where educational materials relating to war and peace and other social issues are available and provides a space for meetings.
projects: We are open to working with students from all majors on developing Capstone Projects that would develop our mission.

name: Pacific Grove Museum of Natural History

name: PMP Pals' Network
description:
This is a grassroots organization without 501(c)3 status.  The PMP Pals' Network is an all volunteer, worldwide resource and referral service for patients, their family, caregivers, and healthcare providers affected by rare cancers originating with the Appendix, including Mucinous Adenocarcinoma, Peritoneal Carcinomatosis, Signet Ring Cell, cancers affecting the peritoneum, cancers affecting the digestive system, and Pseudomyxoma Peritonei.

Organizational Goals:

- To assist and serve newly diagnosed patients, and their caregivers, as a source of information and referrals to physicians experienced in the treatment of cancers of the Appendix, Pseudomyxoma Peritonei, and all mucin producing cancers originating from the Appendix.  Our database includes an international listings of surgeons, oncologists and pathologists experiencing in treating Pseudomyxoma Peritonei and related diseases.

- To share resources and information to assist patients in living well with the challenges of Pseudomyxoma Peritonei.

- To provide assistance to patients and their family caregivers in preparing for, and recuperating from, surgery and/or chemotherapy.

name: Population Services International
description:
PSI is an international nonprofit organization with local offices in Watsonville.  PSI provides information, services and products aimed to reduce the rates of unintended teen pregnancy and to promote HIV/AIDS awareness in Santa Cruz and Monterey counties.

PSI has more than 30 years experience in designing and operating reproductive health, HIV/AIDS prevention, and other health-related social marketing programs in more than 60 nations around the world.  

PSI¿s Central Coast project was started in 1999 to promote responsible sexual behavior among teens.  Youth leadership is integral to all aspects of PSI¿s programming from strategic planning to program design and implementation.

The Central Coast project is predominantly focused on rural communities in Santa Cruz and Monterey counties, where there is a demonstrated need for increased access to information and resources about sexuality:  
·Half of high school age teens are sexually active.
·Less than half of sexually active teens report using contraceptives every time they have sex.
·Watsonville and Salinas have some of highest teen pregnancy rates in the country.
·Teens are the fastest growing number of new HIV cases.
·One in four teens will contract a sexually transmitted disease during adolescence.

PSI promotes responsible sexual behavior through a multi-faceted approach combining community mobilization, teen-produced media, and skills building for youth and parents. Successes of the Central Coast project include:
·ShoutOut, a highly acclaimed quarterly teen newspaper.
·Amor y Deseo at Heartville High, an award winning 12-part teen radio novella. 
·Habla Conmigo, parent workshops on how to talk with kids about sex.  
·Teen Advocates, a group of teen leaders who advocate for increased information and access to contraceptives.
projects:
PSI would like to develop a website for ShoutOut.  The website design will be fairly complex, with search engines, moving imagery, monthly online quizes, question and answer sections, etc.  PSI is looking to fill one of the following internships (depending on capability and time commitment of intern):

Website Advisor: Intern would review the proposals submitted from multiple web designers, meet with PSI staff and program partners and develop a strategy/plan for web site development and implementation.

Website Coordinator: Intern would work with PSI staff, teens and web designers to create a web site for ShoutOut.

While PSI staff is extremely eager to create a website for ShoutOut, we also realize that it will demand a lot from an intern.  The challenges are that the proposed website is very complex.  Serving as either an advisor or coordiantor for the web site will require immersing oneself in a lot of information and options without extensive guidance from PSI staff.  We need someone who is motivated, self-directed and very techinical, yet able to understand the objectives of our teen program.

description: Mission Statement: The staff and voluteers of the Resource Center for Nonviolence have joined together to promote the conscious practice of nonviolence as a dynamic means of effecting personal change and of creating a more just and peaceful world, by providing resources for critical reflection and constructive action, leadership development, and individual and groups empowerment, and by encouraging diverse groups and individuals to address social problems by life-affirming means and to develop nonviolent alternatives.

name: PVUSD Migrant Ed. Program
description: The Migrant Program is primarily an educational organization dedicated to the academic success of the community of migrant students we servce. Our mission is to advocate for the community of Migrant children and families who reside within the Pajaro Valley Unified School District. We are committed to: Identify the needs of the community we serve and evolve to meet these needs Provide educational guidance and support to maximize the academic and personal achievement of the students and families we serve Advocate for equitable access to community resources Empower the families we serve to utilize available health, social, and educational resources Create and foster forums which celebrate the rich and diverse cultures of the community we serve The Migrant Education Program will achieve this mission through an accountable data-driven decision-making process. Virtually every qualifying family is from Mexico, most of which are from the state of Michoacï¿½n. The vast majority speak Spanish, though a small percentage speak Mixteco and Zapoteco as they come from the State of Oaxaca in southern Mexico.

description: Meals on Wheels of the Monterey Peninsula is guided by the belief that a person's health reflects the nurturing of the whole person - body, mind and spirit. name: Royal Presidio Chapel Project - CSUMB Institute of Archaeology & Diocese of Monterey
description:
The primary initiative of the Institute for Archaeology is to develop a fully integrated curriculum centered on archaeological science, technology, and visualization. This Institute's curriculum encompasses the social, geo-spatial, virtual, environmental, and archaeological sciences. Project-based and both lab and fieldwork oriented, the Institute explores and engages the development of:

· Online and multimedia instructional courseware 

· Archaeology and museum collections database applications 

· Virtual museum development and virtual reality (VR) modeling of archaeological sites and materials 

· An ongoing program of archaeological research and material culture studies 

· Museum design, development, and public programming for the Old Mission and community of San Juan Bautista and other project sites on the California Central Coast 

· Archaeology and museum anthropology applications in Service Learning
projects: Please consult with Dr. Ruben Mendoza, the principal investigator and SBS Professor, regarding your Capstone project ideas.

name: San Benito County Historical Society
description: The Historical Society's collection of artifacts is currently housed inthe Wapple family home.  The museum houses a large collection of vital records to aid geneologists in their search for family history.  The Society's Historical Village is located on 3-acres of a 33-acre county park.  The Village consises of ten major building, displayed as though the occupants have just stepped off to town.  The Village is a work in progress. The Society continues to grow in knowledge of the San Benito County's history.

name: Community Recovery Services - Si Se Puede (Santa Cruz Community Counseling Center)
description:
Sí Se Puede is a residential treatment program certified and licensed by the State to provide comprehensive rehabilitation services to men with drug and alcohol abuse problems.  Services are provided in English and Spanish.

Although Sí Se Puede is designed to be culturally sensitive to the needs of Latino men in recovery, our program also serves all other male populations, races and ethnicities.  The program provides opportunities for men to face their addictions and build a strong foundation for recover.  

The program focuses on behavior and attitude changes, enabling residents to learn to constructively deal with the responsibilities and real tasks of drug and alcohol free living.  It is based on the Denial Management Counseling Model and peer support encompassing the philosophy that residents are responsible for their own thoughts, feelings and behaviors.

name: Shelter Outreach Plus - Marina & Salinas Locations
description:
Shelter Outreach Plus is Monterey Countyâ€™s leader in ending the cycle of homelessness and domestic violence by providing safe housing, compassionate support, and opportunities for self-sufficiency through outreach, emergency shelter, transitional housing, and supportive services.

Shelter Outreach Plus plays a significant role in Monterey Countyâ€™s Continuum of Care for the homeless and victims of domestic violence through its programs of outreach, emergency shelter, and transitional housing. For 30 years, our agency has shown remarkable success in helping people move forward with their lives in a positive and safe manner.

Our agency serves men, women and children through several distinct programs. Last year, we served 1,785 adults, 296 children and made 7,483 referrals through the Family Helpline.

We collaborate with several local agencies to provide comprehensive services to homeless individuals and families as well as families dealing with domestic violence. We work with local organizations, coalitions, leaders, and volunteers to educate and inform the general public and help shape policies affecting victims of domestic violence and those experiencing homelessness.

Shelter Outreach Plusâ€™ programs provide a single-point of entry for people in crisis into a total continuum of care where education, recovery, and employment are viewed as key steps to a safe and self-sufficient life. It is through Shelter Outreach Plus that individuals and families can find safe haven and resolve and begin their rehabilitative process in order to transform their life of homelessness into a life of peace and independence.

name: Shelter Outreach Plus - Homeward Bound
description:
This 18-month transitional living program provides a community setting for women and children who are motivated to take an active step toward an independent, productive and violence-free life through employment and educational activities.
Shelter Outreach Plus operates two 30-60-day emergency shelters that offer women and children safety and assistance as they begin the rehabilitative process necessary to break the cycle of abuse or homelessness.

name: Shelter Outreach Plus - Men in Transition Prog.
description:
The Men in Transition program is currently (12/06) housed in Salinas on Soledad Street. The program provides transitional housing with 18 single occupancy rooms for men who are committed to an independent lifestyle. 
This program incorporates the need for employment, job training, or educational activities as the key component in independent living.
Participants in Men in Transition receive case management, access to job training and educational activities. 

The Men in Transition program provides 14 single occupancy rooms of transitional housing for men who are committed to an independent lifestyle.

description: Is to help our communities meet the challenges of Climate Change and Peak Oil. We develop, assist and facilitate coordination between Local Sustainability Groups, building an organization that empowers the people of Monterey County to themselves create a sustainable society. To date our Local Sustainable Groups are: Big Sur Advocates for a Green Environment (BSAGE), Citizens for Sustainable Marina (C4SM), Green Valley Action (Sustainable Salinas), Monterey Green Action (MGA), Offset Project, Sustainable Carmel Valley, Sustainable Pacific Grove and Sustainable Seaside. CSMC is a member of Transitions US, part of the global movement toward resilient communities. We also work to get all cities in MC to sign the international Urban Environmental Accords and the US Conference of Mayors Climate Protection Agreement.

name: The Women's International Respective
description:
Based in Monterey, California, The Women's International Perspective (The WIP) is the global source for women’s perspectives. The WIP reports news, world opinion, and commentary through our Feature Articles, Byline Portal, Current Headlines, and community blog. Our mission is to provide quality articles from the unique perspectives of women, accessible worldwide, and free to readers.

 

The WIP is a balanced media source that promotes diversity. We are not associated with any religious, political, or cultural affiliation. As a worldwide collective of women writers, The WIP is an opportunity to balance the tremendous under-representation of women journalists and offer a greater diversity of background and opinion than typically found in mainstream publications. The WIP strives to bring together divergent cultures, opinions, and ideas in solution-based dialog.

 

The WIP recognizes our global interconnectedness. Our feature articles offer a more humanistic and contextual view than traditional news stories. They are concerned with the human cost of global policy and the impact of events as they unfold.

 

The WIP honors underrepresented voices – we honor women, we honor the indigenous, we honor the poor. We honor the personal and the invisible – the stories that don’t get press. The WIP honors the freedom that is the gift that comes with the open exchange of ideas, analysis, and opinion.

name: Ventana Wilderness Society
description:
Ventana Wilderness Society's mission is to perpetuate plant and animal species native to the California Central Coast region through habitat and wildlife restoration, education, and research. 

The Natural Sciences After School Program was developed in partnership with the Monterey Bay Charter School in Pacific Grove, CA and the Recruitment in Science Education program in Salinas and Marina.  This science-based after school program is open to children throughout the Monterey area.  Half of our After School program is dedicated to working specifically with underserved, at-risk youth.  Current participants come to us from the Recruitment in Science Education program and the Martin Luther King Jr. Academy in Salinas.

Students are transported to a local wilderness area and introduced to an environment that many of them have never been exposed to or even aware of, despite such close proximity to their homes.  Students are encouraged to observe and journal changes in this site from visit to visit, and to become aware of how they are interconnected with the environment.   

A basic step in protecting the environment and it's resources is the education of our youth, and one of the most important goals we can achieve is to provide opportunities for local youth - especially those who are at-risk or disadvantaged.
projects:
Project opportunities are available through Ventana's Education Program, Big Sur Ornithology Lab, and Condor Recovery Program.

The Education Program
-Evaluation of program effectiveness
-Development of curriculum based on avian research, california condors, or nature awareness.

The Big Sur Ornithology Lab
-Avian research and data collection
-Monarch Butterfly research and data collection (seasonal - Nov. to Feb.)

The Condor Recovery Program
-Radiotelemetry techniques
-Condor behavioral studies
-Public education on endangered species
-Webpage design

name: Watsonville Charter School of the Arts
description:
The Watsonville Charter School of the Arts is a K-8 public charter school.  
The Watsonville Charter School of the Arts is dedicated to equipping students of the Pajaro Valley with the multiple literacies necessary to be successful in the twenty-first century.   These literacies include: communication, language arts, mathematics, multiculturalism, physical education, problem solving, general and social sciences, technology, and the visual and performing arts.

The end product of these literacies will be students who have the skills and abilities to: use many different symbol systems: verbal, mathematical, visual and auditory; be critical and analytical learners, confident decision makers, problem posers and problem solvers, collaborative workers, and imaginative and creative thinkers.

name: Youth Orchestra Salinas (YOSAL) - el sistema - salinas
description:
Youth Orchestra Salinas (YOSAL) is an El Sistema-inspired music program.  Conceptualized more than 35 years ago by Dr. José Antonio Abreu, his efforts ignited a revolution in the world of classical music as thousands of students from the most under served communities of Venezuela began studying music each day after school.

In July 2010, Salinas began its own chapter in El Sistema history, offering music instruction in recorder, strings, and choral methods to students from the Salinas Elementary and Alisal school districts

name: AFTA Associates - Art For The Animals
description: AFTA Associates is a non-profit conservation organization that works in collaboration with existing wildlife and nature conservancy organizations to make consumers aware of endangered species and environmental and sustainability issues; raise money for their wildlife research, education and training programs; and to make the business of conservation, a business from which local communities can make a living.

name: Yielded Vessels Ministries Inc
description: Community Training and Equipping Center - computer training and education facility for families: men, women, youth and children addressing personal and spiritual development.
projects: To be determined.

name: YWCA of Monterey County
description:
The YWCA Monterey County was established in 1972 and focuses on domestic violence. We operate a confidentially- located shelter, 24-hour crisis line early violence prevention in the schools, counseling center and legal advocacy.

The YWCA of Monterey County is to create and provide comprehensive, long-term solutions to end domestic violence and prejudice, and to promote emotionally and economically healthy women and families.

Pathways Program pairs participants up with an adult mentor from the community and provides $2000.00 to overcome barriers that are preventing them from achieving goals.

Youth Education Program is a supportive group for teens to voice their opinions and ideas. It works to change attitudes toward teen violence and domestic violence through peer education and encourages self-esteem.

The YWCA of Monterey County is committed to ending violence, providing refuge and empowering women.

We envision providing all women and girls in Monterey County with pathways to healthy balanced lives.  The YWCA advances societal change through education, collaboration and leadership thereby enhancing the community with empowered successful women.
issues: Youth Development|Women's Issues|Violence Prevention|Social Services|Law & Legal Services|Housing & Homelessness|Health & Human Services|Environment|Education|Before/After School|Arts
